I am not going to lie, this anime is quite full of fan service. However, even without the fan service being taken into account this is quite a fun anime to watch, it is not to deep or anything like that, just a bunch of high school kids kicking some zombie butt. The serious downside is, this show isn't "finished", meaning the plot is not complete, and as far as I know it never will be, so you will be left with a lack of resolution at the end of it. That being said, the best way to describe this anime is fun, and isworth watching.

Overall	
Gore and boobies all at the same time! YAY! No wait... 
Seriously, this was a waste of time as huge as the female characters' racks! Basically, if you ignore the zombies, it's just a harem anime with unusually shallow characters and an extraordinarily stupid script.
If you want gore, check out Elfen Lied or Gantz, and if you want fanservice, I'm sure you'll know where to look.
Animation	
This is one of the best looking anime I have ever seen. The graphics and visual effects are just stunning!
Too bad the character designs are not as top notch. Most people look dull and uninspired. And the actual animation isa little stiff. But still, High school of the dead looks great, there's no denying that.


...but why do all the boobies behave like balloons filled with clabber?


Sound	

Opening and ending themes are really bad. I FF:ed through it to spare my ears. Background music is also pretty meh. Sound effects are great though. Awesome gunshot samples and the zombies sound really zombie:ish.


Voice acting is also really good. Too bad no one is ever saying anything worth paying any attention to...


Story	

Short version: Stupid.


Longer version: Stuuupid! How a studio can throw money on graphics and voice talent while letting a cow write the script and dialogue is beyond me. The first episode was very promising, but soon the dreaded irrationality that many anime share took over completely. 


Every scene is filled with and based on irrational and unbeliveable behaviour which makes all credibility go out the window. 


There is also no backstory; both the metaplot and the characters are incredibly shallow.


Character	

Really shallow and stereotypical characters here. Nothing we haven't seen before in just about every bad harem anime out there. 


Plus, they all act stupid beyond belief.


Value	

The Coalgirls fansub was not that bad. Constantly lousy timing, but I could live with that as it didn't really matter what anyone said anyway.


Will not watch again.

I watched HotD with low... low expectations. I quickly corrected my attitude towards it when I realized how hooked I was. Now I am sad there are no more seasons of it. That's why I've re watched it a couple of times.
The general story is pretty poor by itself, its another zombie like viral infection that isn't explained not one bit. Zilch. But the story of the characters and their adventure together is very nicely portrayed. In the beginning I hated the girl with the pink hair, but at the end I was so bonded with the story I felt her character. If that's notbeing hooked onto something, idk what is.


The art is kind of different than your usual anime, the characters aren't portrayed in a "real" manner, but there is more reality to the drawing, less bulgy crystal eyes. 


While I can see the harem in it, its less of a fight between the girls for the guy because of their desire to survive, which is awesome IMO. Because you get the harem, but no bullshit from the characters who are lining up for senpai to notice them. 


I HIGHLY recommend it.

I wanted something lighthearted to watch (storyline-wise) and I got what I wanted. 
Granted, this story line doesn't have the most amazing story line, it's more like boobs, boobs, action, and then more boobs. So yes my fellow ecchi lovers if you are a bit of a pervert then you will be rewinding and re-watching some of the scenes in this anime over, and over, and over again. Sometimes I wonder if the director thought how far can I go until I make this a hentai? Anyway, like I said, the story isn't amazing.
Needless to say this anime starts off with a bang. All hellhas broken loose and even though it's a bit odd how this whole thing started, we don't care because there's hot chicks running around and dudes bashing up zombies. The fight scenes were awesome, between the slow-motion, the awesome sound track and bouncy boobies it's no wonder 22 minutes per episode went by so fast. 


In some places this anime made me laugh, and unexpectedly so. I cannot reveal as to which parts, but people who have already viewed this anime will know what I'm talking about. I loved the characters and in a way I'm kind of glad the MALE protagonist for this first time in an ecchi seemed to have made his mind up on which female he liked! And it was also finally a female character that I actually liked! 


Overall, this series isn't something you'd watch for it's plot or deep storyline, i'm so sick of people reviewing this like "Yeah it's got zero plot" as if they were comparing it to something like Angel Beats or Another. (both great animes Go watch them by the way) 


So if you want to see sexy chicks in skimpy clothing fighting off zombies and laugh at just the sheer ridiculousness of some of the generic (yet funny) characters in this anime. Then go and watch HSoTD.

Highschool of the Dead is a good anime that could have been a great anime if only it had taken itself seriously. Its story is solid and well paced, the art is fantastic, and the characters are introduced in a way that makes you care about them although very little background is given (though considering this is only a 12 episode anime thats fine).
Story: 7
When I first started watching this anime, based on what I had heard I expected it to be an anime about breasts and panty shots that just so happened to have zombies in it. While the anime does have enough pantyshots and breast bounces to embarrass Dead or Alive Beach Volleyball, the story is all about the zombies. The way the zombies are introduced to the plot is nice. Almost each episode has the characters trying to accomplish a goal in an effort to reach their long-term goal of surviving. The plot is well paced and fits nicely in the 12 episodes of the series. Another thing I appreciated about the story is there are not a lot of plot holes left by the end of the season and much of the story is plausible (once you accept the whole zombie premise). 


The main problems with the story is that at times it tries to get deep and you start to take it seriously from a psychological perspective...and then just when you are about to be drawn into a scene the animators go "LOOK BOOBIES!", and the spell is broken.


I wont spoil much about the ending but really I thought they could have done more with some earlier plot points to make the ending more memorable. Suffice it to say the way the show ends basically demands that it get another season or at least an OAV.



Art: 8


One thing I was not expecting from this series was the spectacular art. Computer animation is used really well in some scenes, particularly actions sequences. The scenery is pretty too and really adds to the whole "end of the world" tone of the story. One last note on the art...some of the breast physics really do put Dead or Alive to shame. Not only are most of the camera angles centered around showing of the guns that the women are carrying and those that are attached to their chests, there are some moments where the boobs look like they have themselves achieved sentience and are fleeing the zombies all on their own.



Sound: 6


The sound on the other hand was mostly so-so. The voice actors all did a decent job (including Eri Kitamura as Saya Takagi...what is it with her and characters named Saya). The opening theme had some neat moments but I found myself skipping it most of the time. The music in the show itself was forgetable for the most part. I mean it worked with the action scenes and the sad scenes and what not but there wasnt any time in this anime where the music really blew me away.



Character: 7


Like all good zombie apocalypse stories, each character in High School of the Dead serves a function that aids in the survival of the group: 


-We have the main hero who starts out all whiny and emo and then starts to grow and mature towards the end while the others look up to him.


-We have the main heroine who made a promise to the main character when they were kids and then (for reasons that are vaguley hinted at late in the series) ends up with another guy...oh and she can use a spear really well.


-We have the typical mostly stoic but mature and attractive katana wielding high school girl who acts like a big sister by cooking meals (wearing ONLY an apron) and cutting apart zombies when she isnt doing that.


-We have the bitchy genius girl who its hard to like at the beginning but who grows on you by the end of the anime. (as usual Eri Kitamura plays this type of character very well).


-We have the Otaku who is useless in the real world but in the Zombie Apocalypse he is an awesome weapons expert who turns a nail gun into a nail gun gun (no literally, he adds a stock and uses it like a rifle to kill zombies in the second episode).


-We have the little girl who shows up about halfway through the series and whose three primary functions are to look cute, bring ammo to the otaku, and keep the main characters from making out when she is on screen.


-And finally we have the designated driver, in this case a klutzy, borderline retarded nurse who does not actually have breasts but is in fact smuggling a pair of watermelon-sized marshmallows under her shirt. Her functions are to drive cars, provide comic relief, and to be in charge of fan-service...because if there is one thing this anime didnt have enough of, its fan service (heavy sarcasm).


Honestly I found myself liking most of the characters by the end and you do really hope that most of them live through the zombie apocalypse which is absolutely necessary for this kind of story. Also the characters are mostly believable too. Other than the Otaku, none of the other characters are able to pick up a gun and score headshots from the word go. In fact there is a lot of misses and fumbling around with ammo early on to remind you that these are high school kids. Of course then the katana-girl shows up and makes it look easy but I will forgive that because she looks so darn good while doing it.



Enjoyment: 7


This is a fun anime to watch. However its really disappointing that the anime fails to take itself seriously. There was SO much room for psychological twists or character growth but this was all filled in with breasts and panty shots. Now this being an anime, breasts and panty shots sort of go with the territory and to the anime's credit, these common shots do not distract from the story too much...MOST of the time.


One action sequence in particular I have taken to calling "booby-bullet time". The hero has to fire a sniper rifle off the breasts of another character (for a contrived reason that technically works but you know the only reason they did this was to cause the girl to moan every time the weapon fires). As the hero fires the rifle we get a slow motion sequence where the katana girl backflips to the side to dodge the shots. In slow motion we see her breasts flopping in mid flip  and the bullet goes in front of the first breast and then behind the second one...that sequence all by itself kept this anime from getting a 8 rating. There is fan service and then there is not even trying.


Overall: 7


Like I said, this is a good anime and I recommend that you watch it if you like this kind of genre but it could have been a great anime if it had only taken itself seriously and toned down the boobies.

This anime is not for the faint hearted. It is full of  gore and a few echhi scenes, but this doesn't make it not worth watching. The animation itself is great and the story isn't half bad and makes sense. it gives the feeling of a horror, action, sci-fi movie and doesn't let you down.
Even though it is a short series it gives you what you want in the action area, not dwelling on anything too long.
To some everything up it is a great anime which should be enjoyable to watch.

If you like zombies and hot girls than this anime is all you ever wanted.
I can be very short about this anime, it has no deeper plot (it's a zombie invasion) but it doesn't need a bigger plot. It is about those high school kids trying to survive and kill as many zombies in order to get to the beach and rescue their parents.
The story:
The story is nice, I mean a zombie invasion and some people trying to survive, it has been done for a million times. But this anime differs itself from normal zombie films/series. First of the blood and gore are amazing, peopleget eaten alive etc. This really gives you the adrenaline of fighting those zombies yourself. 

The second thing about this anime is that the zombies, aren't that slow or that weak, normally zombies die after one blow to the head and their quantity is their real strength. In this anime the zombies are actually very strong and they won't be knocked back if you hit them (although they are brain dead). The last thing witch really amazed me was the incredible scenery, we see so much from the city they live in. Although the title said high school they are only in this high school for 2/3 episodes. After they leave this high school they enter the world of madness created by the zombie virus. And in their quest to find their parents and to find a save place they learn to know each other.


Characters:


One thing really points out right away. The fan service in this anime is close to hentai, we see bouncing boobs flying skirts and even a bathtub orgie at one point. The anime gives you so much fan service that I sometimes checked for the door hoping that my parents wouldn't walk in asking me questions I could not explain. 


What I can say about this fan service, well I don't care for it. It is nice to have it and to watch it. I mean who doesn't want to see zombies beat up by hot chicks. It is the same as in movies as transformers were Megan Fox plays for a sex symbol. 


But back to the topic, the characters.

The main character is a smart boy witch is very angry most of the time. He travels with a obese nerd who loves weapons and who can turn from a nice shy boy into a zombie mass murderer within the second he holds a gun. The girls in the anime are amazing. They each have their own personality and certain beauty or style in the anime.


We have the control freak who has a rich background, witch you will learn during the series.

We have the hot ninja girl witch is pretty cliche but she looks hot and you get to learn her past as well. And of course we have the ex-girlfriend of our main character, witch is a nice and fierce girl but also shy and cute, well to get to the point. The characters have it all.


One exception is the school nurse who is annoying as hell, she cannot do a single thing, she is oversexed and well I wonder how someone like her could ever be a school nurse. Ah well.


Verdict:


I truly loved this amazing ride, the zombies the woman, the blood and gore. Everything a boy can dream of. But what I liked most of all in the entire anime, is the music and one song in particular. The opening song is so amazing that I cannot stop listing to it! Normally I skip trough the intro of a episode but with this anime I watched it every time. 


The story is amazing and the ending gives hopes for a second season, the violence and the fan service make this anime to be one of a kind in the blood and gore section. I advice everyone to watch this anime, but please close your doors or it will lead to awkward questions.

 Sigh parents..


Cheers Lucid.

You love zombies and apocalypse stuffs ? You love big boobs, panties and anime girls ? Then this is your anime . 1 lucky dude with 4 hot girls and 1 nerd guy team up  to survive and go find their parents.
You will find a lot of awesome gore parts , but when u'r rdy to get disgusted a random pair of boobies or panties appears and you're brain gets confused, because you don't know if you should be afraid or exited with a boner.
If you got bored of Tokyo Ghoul, Hunter x Hunter or other animes with a lot of drama/emotional things Irecommend to watch this short and funny anime. \n
Honestly I enjoyed watching this anime and I hope there will be a new season.\n
PS: Sry for my bad english.\n

Takashi is skipping class when he notices someone in the courtyard getting bitten. Sensing something bad is about to happen, he then proceeds to go slap a couple bitches, grab a couple weapons, and kick some undead ass. From there boobs fly, tits jiggle and you have yourself “High School of the Dead” in a nutshell.
The core of the anime however tackles some more serious tones. It shows the desperation and development of the cast as they are forced to adapt to the changing world, where anarchy takes the streets, and comfort is but a fleeting dream. It shows the concerns for their families, friends,and cohorts while challenging the very morals they grew up with. Having said that, it is quite hard to take this anime seriously when the amount of fan service presented throughout is enough to freeze over Egypt (get it? Fan?). 


If you want to get a feel for what this anime is like. Just imagine high school, but with guns… and tits, and zombies. Actually, despite being an anime with the word “High School” in its title, the majority of the anime takes place elsewhere, where they seek shelter in various locations and settlements while searching for their family members and a safe haven. 


One of my gripes with watching this show is, the main villain teacher guy… douchefag. Who happens to be a condescending, arrogant, and manipulative twat… who also happens wears a dick on his head. Guess what happens to him in the end? *spoiler* They let him go… Oh For Fucks Sake. “Come on! Shoot his ass Lee! If you ain’t gonna shoot him, kung fu his ass or something!”


There were a couple things in this anime that didn’t register with me; like how Hirano conveniently took shooting lessons in America, how Shizuka’s friend happened to be a special forces operative, how Takagi’s parents happened to be Batman and Wonder woman, why all the breasts seemed to be shaped like NFL footballs, and how Saeko’s breasts seemed to be two completely separate entities (heh titties) that seemed to defy the very laws of physics. 

However because this anime was so over the top, you could just enjoy it for its entertainment value and level of ridiculousness. The action scenes were extremely over the top as was the amount of fan service . Meanwhile there‘s a decent amount of humor, ideology, and character development spread throughout. The first season however, doesn’t resolve everything and leaves it up for a second season.


The only problem is, the manga has been put on indefinite hiatus for just over a year now, and plans for a second season are nowhere in sight. Apparently, despite the overwhelming popularity of the anime (currently #27), it was so controversial that they had to put it on pause. 


(Meanwhile, ‘To Love-Ru Darkness’ is apparently “Safe For All Ages”. http://www.sankakucomplex.com/2012/06/03/to-love-ru-darkness-escapes-ban-now-safe-for-all-ages/ (Warning: 18+))

Who the fuck decides this shit, the fucking pedobear?


If you are a fan of; fan service, zombies, footballs, panties, over the top action, and boob physics, then this is an anime I would recommend. Who knows, if you like it, tell your friends, sign a petition or something in hopes that Shoji Sato will take a break from drawing hentai and get back to this series. (Then again with the current rating system, his hentai might even be more “safe” than this series.)


I hoped you enjoyed this review, and as always, thank you for reading.

A quick guide for the unbeknownst.
Highschool of the Dead is: 
A Harem
Highschool of the Dead is NOT:
A Horror
If you like "harem" and that sort of sexual fantasy mixed with sitcom-y type of shows, then give'r a watch. Try to imagine a little less comedy and more hyper "manly" action than your typical harem story. That's probably what you're in for, but I'm not too sure, I don't like harem so you probably know more than I do.
Don't bother reading the rest. 
These aren't the droids you're looking for.
If you're like me then hopefully you can use this review to bypass this show and do somethingbetter with your time. \n
The "fan-service" is immense here.\n\n
Don't understand the concept of "harem" or "fan-service"?\n
A quick mostly-spoiler-free description of what I saw:\n\n
This show has all the straight-male fantasy found in typical 80's action flicks magnified by twenty, only instead of a super-muscular 30-something dude its a slim somehow-really-skilled handsome teen dude, and then add more innuendoes and more awkward teenager dialogue.\n
Most of the (sometimes) thought-provoking commentaries on society found in zombie classics like Romaro's Dead series is tragically absent. Occasionally there's a glimpse to some interesting human interactions but, for the most part, the show focusses on the handsome somehow-really-skilled teenager and his survival group with one unhandsome male "dork" and several female stereotypes with oversized boobs. \n\n
Like, really, really big boobs. Unrealistically big and perky boobs. \n
In this universe, Japan makes a shit-ton of money from breast-enhancement surgery. \n\n
One (maybe two if you're pushing it) of the female characters is skilled in combat and she's a confident person, which seems nice considering, but it's quickly revealed that she ultimately depends on the lead male character and is often used as a tool for the harem storyline. It's personally difficult for me to take a show seriously when some one who's supposed to be a badass finds herself wearing almost no clothing or participating in a wet t-shirt voyeur, just 'cause.\n\n
This isn't to say that's all a bad thing, necessarily. Some of the tropes and styles are really enjoyed by certain audiences, and harem stories are quite popular in Japan for a reason. However, I do not personally find harem and this sort of sexual fantasy interesting. If that's all a show is going to offer then why don't I just go watch some porn, or even better, a live-action erotic film that isn't so over-the-top and childish?\n\n
I was warned of the harem aspect before I started watching the show...\n
I was just hoping that maybe, just maybe, it would offer something else. Something that zombie-flick fans might enjoy or find interesting. Something a little deeper or scary than your average harem story. Unfortunately, the sexual fantasy aspect is really all that's there. Any time the story looks like it could turn interesting it never follows through and then goes right back to the hilariously unrealistic fantasies. Sometimes characters will go through (what should be) horrific experiences then within a couple scenes they're totally fine because they need to bolster the male leads.\n
Priorities, am I right?\n

Story: HSotD is a pretty standard "survivors must escape the zombie hordes" series, only this time our intrepid heroes are a bunch of high schoolers seeking safety while also trying to discover the fates of their families. I always find it intriguing to watch how groups would react when society completely collapses, even more so when it's a bunch of young students trying to fully grasp what this means for them and their futures.
Art: When the action gets going, be prepared for sheer physics defying psychosis forms of entertainment. However, at times the creators go lazy and pull "shaky cam stills" in some of thestrangest places, such as a girl jumping off a bus.


Sound: Sound is pretty much what you would expect from a zombie horror series. I give props to a really good intro song, though I must also warn it is the best song played throughout the series. You may stab your ears out at some of the Engrish sung in the ending scenes


Character: Characters are fairly standard tropes for the genre: the popular guy protagonist, his love interest, best friend, sullen female badass, the "geek that inherited the earth" badass. Some character development, but nothing that makes them stand out. (Seriously, I can't remember any of their names).


Enjoyment: Herein lies the rub. The sum of the parts, while nothing extraordinary, would have made for a fully enjoyable series on their own merits. However, the creators also decided flood the series with so much fanservice it nearly derails the entire thing. By flooding I mean it looks like they added MORE in post production. This isn't some prudish attitude of mine; there's at least one panty or chest shot every 30 seconds or so. It is so prevalent that when you get to the requisite "chicks in a bathtub" scene, you are so numbed you actually don't care.


Conclusion: 6/10 HSotD would have scored higher for me were it not for the excessive and honestly unnecessary amounts of fanservice thrust at you. I won't give a full out recommendation to watch it because of it, but if you are curious the action scenes will melt your brain with their insanity, and you'll find a decent story to boot.

High School of the Dead is more or less something of a parody of zombie movies as a group of high schoolers fight for their lives with the zombie apocalypse hitting the Japanese populace. The anime mostly relishes in the spectacle of seeing zombie hordes getting slain in various ways, the populace struggling with moral inhibitions to ensure self-preservation and plenty of T&A going around thanks to the anime's copious amounts of fan service and ecchi content it shows off. Visually, the anime is one of the better animated 2010 anime titles to be made making creative use of camera positions and effects such asbullet time, zoom shots and swooshing angles to depict the intense zombie-killing action that unfolds, with scenery shots looking vast and well-detailed when the camera pans out to show them off.


While the series is a rarity for anime in being a zombie survival title, it doesn't have much to offer in terms of depth with the plot and characters to High School of the Dead are rather paper-thin. The plot is mostly repetitive as our group of high schoolers have to regularly fight through zombie hordes, find shelter for a period of time, wind up fleeing when their shelter is breached and repeat. It also often disregards proper logic for the sake of its spectacle as characters are known to not make smart decisions regularly in this series and details such as proper government action and ammo supply are often disregarded.


The characters are not much better as they are mostly archetypal and get little in the way of development, most notable of these characters being an otaku who is seemingly a representation of a stereotypical otaku with his enjoyment of shooting his way through zombies and usually relishing in the women that are within his group. Speaking of the women, High School of the Dead has them purposely designed to be well-endowed and sporting a good number of fan service/ ecchi moments with panty shots, breast jiggling, revealing attire, clothes changing scenes, a bath scene and an orgy. The mentioned fan service is mixed in at many points during the zombie battle scenes, with the series clearly aimed at fans of gory action and ecchi titles.


Overall, High School of the Dead mostly gets by with the style it emphasizes with its presentation and premise, while lacking quite a bit on the end of substance. If you don't mind some mindless entertainment, this would make for a decent rental. But if you are looking for more substance or are not a big fan of gore and ecchi content, then this isn't a title worth picking up.

Highschool of The Dead was an alright anime in my opinion. Not terrible, but not great.
Story: The story had a lot of potential. Zombie Apocalypse...sounds pretty sick. But, instead the group of kids in the Highschool decide on trying to find their families. I don't know, I didn't really like that as much as I expected. The story was also quite boring towards the end of the series for me (episodes 10-12). I give it a 6/10
Art: The art was great. The zombies were all drawn very well and nothing looked odd.  Only complaint I have is the girls' hairstyles...I thought they looked stupidhonestly. But I still give the art a 10/10


Sound: The sound was cool. I liked the openings and the BGM's as they all fit within the show. Each episodes ending was a different song, so that was something cool. The English Dub is honestly quite different from the Japanese version including much more profanity and a lot of the lines were different than what they should of been. 9/10


Character: I didn't really like any of the characters much except for Saeko to be honest. The cast is all pretty sterotypical (Normal leader, bratty girl, stupid girl, normal girl, sadistic girl, comic relief guy etc)

No one really stood out a whole lot except for Saeko in my opinion. 7/10


Enjoyment: Besides the OVER-EXCESSIVE USE OF FANSERVICE, I enjoyed it. Even though the end was quite slow in my opinion, it was okay. 7/10


Final thought: Highschool of The Dead is a goodish anime. It's not very memorable (except the fanservice) and won't be in your "Wow that was one of the best animes I've seen!" list. It's worth watching however, since it's only 12 episodes.

Breasts,Guns and Zombies! Those are the three words that sum up High School Of The Dead, and trust me that isn't a bad thing. HOTD is one of those anime that doesn't really care what it does with itself, it'll throw you all the fan-service it wants and all the kick-ass zombie slaying it wants. HOTD really is the definition of an action anime.Though not done perfectly, HOTD really is one of the best at what it does.
The story really isn't anything to write home about, it's your typical zombie plot where you have a group of survivors trying to stay alive in a worldinfested with zombies. It's something i'm sure we've all seen countless amount of times in a movie or TV show. However, like I said before, that isn't at all a bad thing, it's actually one of the things that makes HOTD shine. HOTD has such a basic and braindead plot(see what I did there, he he) that you can focus more on the action and comedic elements of the anime than instead having to focus on a uber complex plot. That's one of the best parts of this anime. Again, it's an anime that you cannot take seriously or else you'll hate it because of all the clear flaws it has when it comes to the story. HOTD does one thing really well when it comes to the story and setting, it has a great presentation of how the world would be if it became littered with zombies. HOTD shows the chaos that would erupt if a zombie apocalypse did occur. This is something that I love in HOTD.


The art and sound in High School Of The Dead is pretty well done, the animation is attractive and every scene involving the desolation of zombies is so awesome to watch. Out of everything in HOTD I enjoyed the action sequences the most just because they were so bad-ass and executed so well.

The only gripe I have with HOTD's action is the fact that in nearly every action scene there are huge, jiggly boobs flashed around everywhere like confetti on New Years Eve. However, I will say eventually you'll get accustomed to the crude amount of fan-service in this anime that is literally every where in High School Of The Dead. I also must say that HOTD has an amazing soundtrack that really compliments all of it's zombie killing. Not to mention that HOTD has a breathtaking Opening that got me excited for every episode.


The Characters in High School Of The Dead are a clear weak point in the anime. Unless of course you like every single one of your female protagonists to pack ginormous tits, than of course you might actually like the cast in HOTD. Our main character Takashi Komuro is at first the standard whiny main persona, Until later where he is forced to evolve into the honorable leader of his zombie survival squad. Takashi isn't really a cool character and is rather bland for the most part. Rei is the love interest of Takashi and is also the one person he vows to protect at all costs. Rei is unfortunately your run of the mill tsundere until they obviously end up together, at least somewhat.

Saeko has to be the second most bad ass character in HOTD, she's a super agile, sword wielding, freak who will tear anything that stands in her way.

She also has probably the most interesting back story of all the characters and has the most skill in slaying zombies. Kohta is the last person that is worth mentioning in this review. He's an otaku that has a wicked passion for guns and killing things. If the group didn't have Kohta, they'd honestly all be toast! Saya Takagi is a quite annoying character that stays like that from beginning to end.She's the smartest of the group but is the most bitchy and almost is a detriment to the ring of survivors. Shizuka rocks the biggest breasts in the anime and is there for pure fan-service. She's the worst character in the anime and I really did want her to eventually die. Alice is the little girl the whole squad valiantly rescues in order to protect her, sadly she isn't so important to the overall chances of survival within the whole group.


Finally, Did I enjoy High School Of The Dead? Yes! I enjoy this anime because it doesn't try to hard to succeed. As dumb as it sounds, the rashness of this anime and the pure recklessness should be enjoyable to anyone. This is the perfect anime if you just want to kick back and have a whole lot of fun.

Zombies fans you are in for a treat.  Highschool of the Dead is a by the book zombie apocalypse that we all know and love except in anime form.  Its not setting new grounds or innovating, but it certainly is entertaining.
The story starts with our protagonists at school at least until the first zombie comes knocking at the school gates.  Everything goes down hill from there and what ensues is a frantic scramble for survival.  Friendships are tested, emotions run high, and zombies are subjected to various forms of trauma before the survivors find a quiet niche to contemplate, relax orotherwise have some downtime.  This repeats throughout, ensuring time for characterisation with the repetition supplemented by scenes of the fall of global society.  It might seem boring but it is well paced.


As you may or may not know, the source material tends towards visual fidelity and gratuitous fanservice.  The anime does not disappoint with great detail spent animating ridiculous fights that defy the laws of physics.  Not to say that the quieter or more rousing scenes suffer.  They don't and some of the picturesque backgrounds do a great job in contrasting the living dead apocalypse.  Characters themselves are given similar treatment, though the fanservice may seem excessive to some.  Arguably, the show was never meant to be that subtle about it given an interview the director (correct me if I'm wrong) gave early in series.


Not to mention the sound work done in to the series.  Not only do the blows seem visceral but the guns do sound realistic as they were.  Supported from below by the background music, the fight scenes really do gain that edge.  In fact, even the opening gets you in to the mood to see more zombie carnage while the ending highlights the sadness of having to wait until the next episode for more.


As for the characters themselves I do want to say I love some of them. I appreciate how each character has their own, well, character.  Some of them are overplayed however, but really I should have expected it.  Especially the ditzy nurse.  Surprisingly enough, its the side characters that clearly show some of the best examples of hypocrisy that I like the most, but that's probably only because they get eaten by zombies.


Coming out of the last episode, I must say I enjoyed following our intrepid survivors as they journey along and look forward to the next instalment (there's even a brief glimpse of a future character at the end).  The violence and fanservice is gratuitous.  Coupled with the depiction fall of global civilisation, there's nothing a zombie apocalypse fan wouldn't want.

Highschool of the Dead
Review By: John Fragglepuss Evans
Highschool of the Dead is a journey into the world of the zombie apocalypse. It is an entertaining anime to watch because it combines a lot of different genres. For example, there are zombie battles that combine violent action with horror, but then bits of comedy and fan service will be thrown in mid-battle. At least I find it humorous when they throw in fan service mid-battle. This anime was a fun watch all the way through. It is a shame that Japan is not into zombies as much as America, otherwise we may have had a secondseason.


You might enjoy this if: Zombies are your thing.


You might not like it if: Fan service is not your thing.


Note to the Viewer: There is no shortage of creativity for zombie killings in Highschool of the Dead.

High School of The Dead had the potential to be a truly great zombie series. However, as you should be able to tell by the opening credits, this show devolves into a brainy stew of zombies and fan service. While this combination may seem fine, the show fails to execute, in that, it takes it's self too seriously whilst delivering a mediocre story with little to no character development outside of the one brilliant character of the series, Saeko, the rest of the cast serve as cardboard cutouts compared to her.
What the series lacks of in story, it excels in the art department (Gravity defyingboobs aside) animation is both slick, and vapid, while offering up a great color palette to contrast the brilliant blood streams.


Overall, I'm sure HoTD pleases a majority of it's viewers, and it is an enjoyable viewing experience if you can get over the awkward fanservice and don't expect a serious plot. The most disappointing aspect of the series is that it offers an otherwise fascinating insight into what people would do if a zombie outbreak were to happen, however these instances of fascination are few and far between and takes a backseat to the series' main goal, pandering to it's teen male demographic. 


If you're looking for a mindless zombie slaying experience then HoTD is for you, otherwise don't get your hopes up.

This story is a teen aged fantasy incarnate. Blood, gore, ecchi, every teenager's apocalypse plan gone right. While it certainly isn't original, it does what it set out to do, and that's to be a zombie apocalypse adventure. Action packed, pure awesome fight scenes with chicks who know how to kick some ass!!! It's ecchi, so yeah there are a lot of boobs, which may or may not be a bad thing. 
The art style wasn't anything special but it had great gore, lots of blood and no censoring, which matched the music quite well and created a great fight scene atmosphere. 
Character development ispresent but barely. The characters are definitely stereotypical and lack depth to say the least, however the cast is relatable, they enjoy - to some extent - what's happened just as many teenagers wish the zombie apocalypse would just happen already. Which, in my opinion, is all that this show needed them to be.\n\n
If you just want to sit back and watch some hot teens kick the ass out of some zombies this is an excellent pick.\n

Story:
The story in HOTD is nothing special. A group of highschoolkids and a ditzy nurse with giant breasts trying to survive a zombie apocalypse. Although some relationships are formed, they are weak at best. Aside from that, it is still an enjoyable story that is enough to keep you watching. 7/10


Art:

The art in HOTD is done very well done. It has a dark art style that fits nicely with the theme of a zombie apocalypse. The characters look good and so do the zombies. 9/1


Sound: 

I didn't even notice the sound in HOTD which means one thing. It fitted each seen well. That being said, the sound wasn't memorable and I don't think I remember one song from the show. The sound does well to assist the scenes overall feel. 8/10


Character:

The characters in HOTD were average apart from Kouta. Kouta is a nerdy gun maniac that you can't help but love whilst watching the show. 6/10


Enjoyment:

HOTD is not something you should expect a lot from. You just need to sit back and enjoy what it has to offer, which is guns, zombies, blood and titties. If you watch the show like this, you are guaranteed to enjoy it. 8/10


Overall:

HOTD is an enjoyable anime to watch. As long as you don't take it too seriously, I recommend you give this anime a go.

"This is the way the world ends. Not with a bang but a whimper." - T. S. Eliot 
Underneath all the blatant fanservice and mindless bloodshed, Highschool of the Dead digs deep into the psychology of the human mind, showing us the lengths of cruelty and inhumanity us humans can go to in order to save ourselves. During times of chaos, the disgusting and selfish core of human beings are fully exposed for all to see, and the world which was once keen on peace and unity transforms into one of corruption and division. True, the story depicted in the anime is just that -a fictional story and nothing more - but it does serve as an entertaining way to foreshadow the possible state of the world if a similar international crisis were to happen. However, as this is an anime review, other factors besides the story must also be taken into account. 


Art (7/10)

For the most part, the artwork was done quite well. The animation during action-packed scenes was fluid and easy to watch. The zombies were interesting to see given that the animators had no real model to base their work off of. The grotesque features and lethargic, swaying movements of the zombies replicated what I had in mind almost perfectly. On the other hand, I found the character designs to be a bit plain and unoriginal. If this only applied to the side characters, I wouldn't have minded, but when even the main characters look like characters you've seen before, then there's have a problem. In the end, the good cancels out with the bad, resulting in an average score. 


Characters (6/10)

Honestly, I was disappointed with the characters. With the exception of a few scenes, I felt there wasn't enough character development. One would think that, in the situation the characters are in, that there'd be plenty of it. However, all that really happens throughout the series is killing, fleeing and resting. There isn't much dynamic dialogue to contribute to the development of the characters. One specific example of failed characterization is unsurprisingly the school nurse, Marikawa Shizuka. At times, I wondered whether she was there just for the sake of fanservice (as if there wasn't enough already). Despite all this, there were indeed some parts where character development was evident. As an example, when comparing Takashi's character from the start to the end, the changes he has gone through are a testament to his strong, composed and leader-like personality. Similarly, the other main characters have, to a slightly lesser degree, gone through the same. 


Sound (6/10)

From the amusing groans of the zombies to the flurry of mediocre ending themes, the sounds and music used in this show were generally poor. However, the fast-paced opening was effective in pumping me up for each and every episode. Also, the seiyūs did a great job of voicing their characters. The emotions of the characters were conveyed well through their voices, making scenes more realistic and believable. Lastly, the BGM was not memorable; I can barely remember any of the tracks despite having just finished the series. 


Story (8/10)

At first glance, Highschool of the Dead is another one of those typical, post-apocalyptic stories centered on the concept of "survival of the fittest". While this does end up being the case, there were also other messages placed throughout the 12 episodes. Furthermore, even though it'll most likely be useless information, the anime makes an indirect attempt at educating viewers about what might happen if the real world were to end up like what was shown. Personally, I liked how the story was about the journey of a group of high school students trying to survive a zombie apocalypse, even if there was some unrealism to it. 


Overall (7/10)

For those who don't mind a repetitive show that features several large-breasted girls (and two regular, teenage boys) slaying zombies, then by all means, give Highschool of the Dead a try. This is one of those shows that don't require one to think too hard about what's going on (in fact, not thinking is probably the best choice as many things that push the limits of reality are shown). It's a surprisingly popular show, nonetheless, so even if you don't fit into the description of the target group, there may be a chance that you'll still like the show. As for me, I thoroughly enjoyed it. Having also read the manga, I'm glad that there's still material left for the possibility of the second season. To sum it all up, HOTD is essentially your run-of-the-mill fanservice anime.

I have a rule about reviewing series I haven't seen all of: I don't do it.
Breaking that rule for High School of the Dead because it is SO BAD that I have to type about how bad it is.
I love zombies. I have all of George A. Romero's movies on DVD, originals and remakes. I read the Walking Dead comics. I play lots of zombie video games. I read lots of zombie books.
Even zombies couldn't save this show for me. The premise is pretty cool. Students in a high school when the zombie apocalypse starts have to use the resources on their campus the survive.The zombies are pretty cool.


The characters are abysmal and the show is blatantly sexist. I get fanservice. I get that horror often exploits sex (uh, I read the Walking Dead, remember?), that doesn't excuse how EVERY SHOT in this show is fan service, the character designs are awful, no woman wears a bra (who needs one when your school uniform has boob socks! Seriously, show, boobs don't work that way), and all the female characters are unlikable or constantly needing to be saved.


And I seriously doubt zombies are into groping. This is like one degree away from hentai. Nothing against porn, but the porn needs to stay in the porn section and hentai is usually uncomfortably rape-y anyway.


There is exactly one competent female character and she's a yanki stereotype, which distances her from being a "normal" girl so those "normal" girls get to stay sexual objects that get saved because they are sexual. Good job, show.


Even if it gets better--I'm not going back in to find out--that doesn't excuse how awful it was to start out and how utterly alienating it was. All the "girl's are weak and dumb" subtext coupled with constant bouncing boobs and panty shots when these girls are in mortal danger was a neon sign saying "This is not for you, this is for teenage boys".


Seriously, if a woman is being attacked (even by zombies), we should be worried for her, concerned, rooting for her to win, interested in her as a character and her ability to get out of the situation. We should be feeling for her, not oggling her and seeing every attack as another opportunity to see some of her clothes get torn off.


This show is bad and the creators should feel bad.


Also, the music sucks.

São poucos personagens mais eles são muito bons(não estou considerando por que a maioria são meninas e o anime é ecchi,acho que vocês estão me entendendo hehe),cada um tem seu talento,seu jeito de pensar e seu estado físico e eles tem o mesmo objetivo(que não é exatamente um defeito).Meu personagem preferido é o Hirano Kouta(gordinho)por que ele é engraçado,FODA, ele é inteligente e sabe tudo sobre armas(CS da vida).

A arte(não estou falando daquilo que vocês estão pensando não kk),trilha sonora,abertura,ending e dublagem são boas.

My wife suggested we rename this anime "Boobies The Anime" and she's very justified in making that suggestion. I've watched (and enjoyed) shows put out by Sentai Filmworks in the past, such as Dusk Maiden of Amnesia, Log Horizon and Knights of Sidonia, which I rated 10, 8 and 8 respectively, so I knew there would inevitably be fan service in this anime as that is simply what that company does. But mannnnnnnnnnn, this is on an entirely different level! The fan service in this anime is beyond excessive. It is constant, it is shoved down your throat and it is not the tiniest bitsubtle. It's to the point where it's arguable that the fan service is priority number one for the show and everything else, including the plot, is a secondary priority.


Despite this, and with my wife and I both certainly not being the target demographic for the unrelenting fan service, we both actually quite liked this anime even though we both felt like we should not have given how unbelievably juvenile it is. Some of the things it does well include loads of action, uptempo pacing with no boring or slow stretches, energetic and fast paced music (which fits nicely with the fast paced, action oriented nature of the show as a whole) and a comparatively believable plot.


Honestly truly if they had simply toned down the fan service- I'm not even necessarily saying get rid of it completely, just tone it down a bit- this was probably a 9. But it really is to the point where it feels like the point of the anime is to show you boobies and there happens to be zombies and stuff going on in the background.


If you're not bothered by fan service, or if you're a teenage boy who actively enjoys it, you'll likely have a good time with this show. Otherwise, while you may still have a good time, as we did, you'll inevitably be rolling your eyes quite frequently and thinking to yourself "enough already". Know what you're signing up for before watching.


+Jumps right into the thick of things- no slow buildup

+Loads of action

+Fast paced, engaging and energetic


-RELENTLESS AND CONSTANT fan service, more so than any other anime I've ever seen

-Unsatisfying ending that lacks resolution


OBJECTIVE RATING- Really hard to say as it probably varies wildly based on what demographic you fall into, but I'm going to say a 7.5


PERSONAL ENJOYMENT RATING- 8.5

For my anime reviews I am going to review the anime on the order of which you would experience while watching an episode of the anime that is being reviewed.
1.Art - The art for this anime didn't really stand out to me that much but that being said, it is definitely not a bad art style.  The art was very unique, I can say that for sure.  The characters chins could have very well been used to slice and serve butter but instead of doing that the creators decided to give 90% of the character models boobs that outweighed a sumo wrestler andonly for that fact can I give art a 10/10.  LOL just kidding XD!   I really though that the art in this anime had a very typical art style but on the other hand, there were things that made it stand out a little more and for that I'll give a 6 for art.


2.Sound - I was very surprised by the songs in this anime.  It really took me off guard and for a show that's known for it's excessive amount of fan service, that's very impressive.  Of coarse the opening is just fricken' hype, but what really took me off guard was the ending songs.  For all 12 of the episodes the endings were different and that mystified me, here's why.  A lot of people don't even listen to the ending songs and it mystifies me that they spent so much detail on the ending songs when that is an apparent fact... maybe thats why there was only 12 episodes.  The opening and ending songs for this anime were very good, but for the OST I can't say the same.  The rest of the OST never added anything to the anime and that is a bit frustrating.  That is why I can say it's almost an outstanding soundtrack, in other words a 9.


3.Character - Well.... I'll be honest about the characters.... they were completely non-lovable.  They never provoked any emotion in me and the only time I enjoyed the characters was when I was laughing at them.  That being said, they ARE NOT THE WORST.  When something stupid or funny happened to the characters I found myself laughing my head off, but in reality they still kinda sucked.  Enough said, I'll give character a 5.


4.Story - I'm sorry for this but I'm going to be very technical with the term "story".  Is the story how an anime depicts it's self, or is it the idea of it's self that is the story.  In this anime I believe the second.  It's completely true that this anime was riddled with bad characters and to much fan service, but technically the story itself was very good.  Now, I know you must be banging your head on a desk right now but hear me out: The subject of zombies in anime is very much avoided in Japan out of respect for the dead and the way Japanese culture is and this anime takes a innovative swing at the subject.  If you tear away the fan service and horrible depiction of this story it becomes something a lot different than what I watched on my screen.  It is not original in western media but in the east that's another story.  I was very entertained when I saw a clash of zombies and Japanese culture and I felt that the story hit the ball out of the park in that way.  It was a very innovative thing for anime in general and now I can see new anime about zombies coming out that are following this trend.  For the story of this anime I would give a 10 but for the poor depiction I can only give it a 9. 


5.Enjoyement - Since the depiction of this story was very weak I tried not to focus on the story, and when I did that it turned out to be very enjoyable.  It was a lot of fun and I didn't have to exhaust myself by getting into another super hardcore anime; it was very relaxing.  I think that if people watch this anime it should not be to watch seriously.  If you stay relaxed and have fun watching this anime you will love it.  I enjoyed HOTD at a 10.


This anime is an overall 8.


*I will also recommend that this anime is only watched by a matured audience.

At the height of the post-apocalyptic zombie horror phenomenon, Highschool of the Dead happens to be a very relevent anime.
Story: 7/10
Highschool of the Dead's story can best be described as half zombie gore and half fan service. This is the story's fatal flaw, the large emphasis on fan service often serves as a distraction from the main plot, it was pointless, when their should have been more focus on the characters. The story takes on a fast pace, however, with the minimal amount of progression in the story the pacing felt offbeat.
Art: 9/10
The art in Highschool of the Dead was simply breathtaking. The inclusion ofcherry blossoms shedding their flowers was beautiful. The characters were drawn exceptionally well and the zombies looked very realistic.\n\n
Sound: 8/10\n
The quality of the sound was very good, one of the best examples can be found in an early episode, that features a teacher dropping a piece of chalk to the ground, that gives off a sound as it shattters.\n\n
Characters: 7/10\n
Due to the excessive amount of fan service, most characters didn't recieve any real development. Takashi, the main protagonist, whilst competent and compassionate, didn't really seem to have any other character quirks and at times I found him to be kind of dull.  As for the female characters, I had a polarizing opinion of some of them. The female characters include: an indecisive sometimes annoying red-head (with big boobs), an annoying, bitchy pink-haired know-it-all (with big boobs), a dumb blonde doctor with tits larger than her brain, and a cute little girl. The one female character who had any sense and was different from your average teen high school girl was Saeko. Saeko was this anime's saving grace in the character department, a sword-wielding badass, she was by far the most interesting and least stereotypical character in the entire anime.\n\n
Enjoyment: 8/10\n
For all its flaws, Highschool of the Dead was very entertaining, and despite finding the fan service to be excessive, I found it to be enjoyable at times. This happened to be my first anime, and since rewatching it I still find it to be entertaining.\n\n
Overall:8/10\n
Highschool of the Dead is great for people that are fans of the zombie genre and fan service. It is also great for those first timers out their. Overall it was a decent anime, it had some gripping zombie fighting sequences, and some decent character moments, but I stil feel that had the amount of fan service been limited, and the length had perhaps been slightly longer, it could have been a better anime than it was.

What can I say? A fantastic series...
-[Warning - Some Spoilersl]-
The story revolves around a number of highschool pupils that find themselves in the middle of a worldwide zombie apocalypse without any word of its cause.  The highschoolers group together and bond with each-other's differences and share each one of their specialities to each other in their bid for survival.  
Takashi Komuro is the main protagonist who is projected to be a 'dropout' in the future however when the zombie up rise he starts to gradually change for the better.  He shows natural talent to be a looked up 'leader' of the groupdisplaying an 'all-round' style of combat particularly with the bat and eventually a shotgun.  The other characters Rei Miyamoto, Saeko Busujima, Kouta Hirano, Saya Takagi and Shizuka Marihawa all show their talent in the group varying from swords, staffs, guns, intellect and medical care.  


The antagonist (besides the zombies) is Shidou Koichi, a creepy teacher obsessed with creating a 'new world' by intimidating followers into 'religous cult' like group.  Despite is overpowering prowess over most of the characters , the main characters can see right through him and show no mercy when pushed.  Since we know what the others have been through in terms of surviving he personally avoids it as much as possible, which explains his scare when Hirano turns on him.   


The initial objective in the series to go to each of the main character's houses to check on their family and along the way we meet some interesting characters; some psychopaths and some good willed individuals that want help even if they are prone to losing their life.  As it progresses to its conclusion it leaves you in a position that greatly shows its encouragement to show much more.  I think its story is definitely a refreshing idea compared to the conventional idea of a world gone upside down.  Even adding ecchi and comedy moments in a world where all is lost.


My Review: I gotta say this series got me by the end of the seat.  The first few episodes are pretty serious showing alot of graphic gore of the apocalypse of students from zombies biting them, students hurting others to escape and even betrayal of supposedly solid friendships.  Overtime the series loosens up despite the chao's to show some hinted romance and even comedy moments while maintaining the serious atmosphere from the undead.   The music I thought was a masterpiece, face paced industrial music combined with errie suspense underscores to really drives the story


Verdict: 10/10


I am not a horror fan (in fact I don't like it), but this series was fantastic and well structured to be an enjoyable series to watch and I pray that a 2nd season will be made.  ++MUST WATCH!++

I really enjoyed this anime. There are only 12 episodes so it gets to the point and, after watching Elfen Lied (an anime infamous for its "gore" which I was unimpressed by), I'm pretty happy. 
Story: The story is pretty typical. Students at high school who don't normally interact come together as a united front against a mysterious zombie attack. I didn't realize it was an ecchi before I started watching it, but I've seen ecchi before. It got pretty annoying at times when you'd see shots of panties and boobs would bounce everywhere, but that's what I get for watching ecchi so I'm notupset. Also, the story starts out very strong. The characters get into intense battles with the zombies. You can see every detail in the fights, but it starts to fizzle after awhile.


Art: I really enjoyed the art. It was clear, the shading and environments were nicely done and, I have to say, the gore was pretty amazing. I gave it the highest score mostly because of how impressed I was at the beginning.


Sound: The sound was nicely done. They make sure the zombies moan and groan like they are supposed to. The music was haunting and ominous at first(even gave me chills a couple of times), the screams really freak you out at times, but I think they started to tone that down with the action as well. I think they even "borrowed' the Resident Evil theme song...?


Character: I gave this a Fair score because, while the characters had their own stories, it was mostly bouncing boobs and panty shots. They didn't delve too deep into their pasts or relationships in the sake of ecchi related scenes, but again... its to be expected.


Enjoyment: I really enjoyed this anime. The only reason its not higher is because of the in-your-face ecchi (which got uncomfortable at times) and how the rawness of everything just started to fizzle out as it went on.


I'd recommend this anime to anyone who likes zombies and girls (or girls who can get past the pervertedness like me). It was really well done in my opinion and I definitely think its worth a watch at some point.

You're sitting in school one day, skipping class. Your genius friend comes to berate you for being so stupid, your childhood crush is dating your best friend, your grades aren't great and you don't have much direction in life. In other words, a usual day. Suddenly you see an undead monster bite a teacher, and from there you can see what happens - all Hell breaks loose, literally, and your first instinct is to save your friends who haven't been treating you all that well recently. Now you have to deal with relationship drama and zombies attacking from every angle; fun, right?
Highschool of the Deadis nothing if not simplistic. It has just about every cliche one might expect from a zombie story, so anyone looking for something they have never seen before should look elsewhere. However, it is quite a bit of a breath of fresh air in the anime genre; Western stories are filled with zombie apocalypse scenarios, so much so that one must be exceptional (or a decent comedy) to stand out. Anime, on the other hand, hasn't had the same oversaturation of the zombie genre, so the sort of generic anime antics are applied to what one might think is a worn-out idea to bring about something more interesting than at first glance.


Gratuitous ecchi is rampant in Highschool of the Dead. Understandable, as the artist Shōji Satō is quite used to drawing for h-doujinshi and the like. Luckily for him, this artstyle of his fits seamlessly into the world of Highschool of the Dead, and Madhouse did quite an impressive job in translating his art to an anime form. As a result, the adaptation is almost panel-for-panel correct, with only a few creative liberties taken by Madhouse, and this is definitely something to be thankful for as there really wasn't anything to change to make it work.


The story itself, as I said before, is simplistic to the point of being very predictable. While this might normally be a bad thing, it actually adds some charm to the series for a few reasons. One is as I said above - anime doesn't have zombie stories around too often if at all, so from that perspective there isn't much that can be generic for the genre. Another is that the normalcy is almost welcome in the zombie genre at this point; too many zombie stories have been written recently using irony, over the top comedy, and post-modernism in order to avoid the inherent silliness of a zombie movie. Fortunately one of anime's high points is that it rarely takes itself too seriously unless it really wants to, and on the other side of the spectrum it is almost never afraid to go the whole nine yards with an aspect before giving into the absurdity of it all and attempting to add other unnecessary things such as irony in order to appear more "edgy." Perhaps that is the reason that the entirely normal and reasonably simple storyline of Highschool of the Dead is still very entertaining.


The third and final reason Highschool of the Dead is an enjoyable addition to anime is that the genre actually does lend itself to things anime rarely sees other than zombies - male protagonists that can stand on their own two feet. Takashi, the main character, begins the story appearing to be a normal dejected anime lead, but as soon as the situation gets serious he takes things into his own hands and begins protecting the people around him without hesitation. He still has some of the issues with girls that most anime characters do, but he doesn't whine about them, he deals with them, and when an issue arises he deals with it himself. The other male lead, Hirano, is another anime stereotype-breaking character. He's overweight, wears glasses, and is a gun freak; being obsessive and overweight almost always makes you absolutely useless in anime. However, he takes his chance to shine and from there becomes one of the biggest offensive forces in the group, as well as earning the respect of even the most judging people around him.


All in all, Highschool of the Dead may not be the most original anime ever, and it may not have the best written story. But it is truly entertaining for various reasons, the biggest of these being its uniqueness when considering the plethora of endlessly rehashed anime that appear so often. In this regard, it is definitely worth at least checking out.

Lately, there has been a sudden interest in zombies and multiple TV shows, movies, and novels have been made on this topic. The well-known “High school of the Dead” tells a story of a group of high schoolers surviving a zombie outbreak. Because there have been multiple successes with this type of show (ie. The Walking Dead), it grabbed a lot of attention fast. Even though the concept promised success, the result was poor. Outrageous characters, random story development, nonsense back stories, and poorly timed fan service all made the show worse than it should have been.
But before I criticize it, I’ll start with someof the positive things. Throughout the show, there are small side stories told about the people outside of this high school group. They tend to be more realistic and believable. Because they are realistic, probable situations, they are more interesting to watch than the main story itself. They also manage to evoke emotions and set the mood the show was meant to present. In addition, the animation runs quite smoothly. The fight scenes are exciting and not at all choppy (with the exception of few). Another interesting part of the show is the unique method they chose to present humans. The writers chose to show both light and dark side of humans. Unlike most characters in shows, everyone in HOTD acted like a human. They weren’t always good, and they weren’t always evil. It was able to portray what people would actually do during a crisis.


Now that the positives are out, I will talk about the negatives of the show. I’ll start off with the characters. It seems that characters were created in a way to allow writers to have an easier time explaining situations. This made for characteristics that are ridiculous and over-the-top. This may sound all right, but as the show progresses, their characteristics seem to amplify and become more and more ridiculous. In addition, the backstories that come with the characters are far too unbelievable. From being a daughter of an insanely rich family to being trained by a soldier in the US, they come out of nowhere and expect the viewers to comprehend them. The overall story is not much better. Every time they are stuck in a sticky situation, something miraculous occurs to help them out. Every solution is too convenient, ending up making the whole scene anticlimactic. The final, most obvious, mistake of the show is the timing of fan service. Fan service can be found in most anime so it is expected. But intentionally showing them in the middle of an intense scene takes away the seriousness of the situation. I am not necessarily saying that fan service ruined the show and there shouldn’t be any, but the timing producers chose to put them in is just stupid. 


Do I recommend it?


I do not recommend this anime to anyone. There are some interesting side stories, but that one factor cannot redeem other failing parts of the show. HOTD is simply not worth the time.



(When I talk about this with my friends, they all say it is an anime and it is expected to be ridiculous. I do not have a problem with ridiculous shows, but I believe when a show starts out with the intention of being realistic, they should stick with it.)

This is without a doubt the most UNDERRATED anime in recent years.
STORY (8)
The anime may not have much plot but there's still a story to it. Every episode maters and the writing is surprisingly strong. It even has a few backstories that reflect towards the character development.
ART (9)
The art is beautiful. The character designs are great and the fanservice is awesome. It really shouldnt be complained about. Episode 8 had one of the most rediculous but well animated scenes ever.
SOUND (9)
The background music does a nice job of setting the mood. The opening theme gets you really pumped up. The ending themes by Maon Kurosakiare whether upbeat or melancholic close the show perfectly.\n\n
CHARACTER (90\n
Takashi fills out the main character role pperfectly. He's not too wimpy or too stupid and all his actions are realistic yet admirable. Hiran is a very fun characterand provides a lot for the show. Whether he's being comedic or serious. The nurse is adorable and even has a motherly side to her. As for the other characters I'll avoid talking about them because that'll lead to spoilers.\n\n
ENJOYMENT (9)\n
Who DIDN'T have a blast watching this show???\n\n
OVERRALL (9)\n
It's a quality show and it doesnt deserve all the hate it gets. Highschool of the Dead is worth your time.\n
