Highschool of the Dead is an anime inspired by the manga of the same name containing ecchi and horror elements, launched in 2010 by Madhouse studio (the same as Death Note and Devil May Cry), with 12 episodes and a short OVA. In the plot, a sudden zombie outbreak begins to ravage the world where Komuro Takashi and other students (Miyamoto King, Takagi Saya, Hirano Kouta and Busujima Saeko) and Marikawa Shizuka nurse will have to confront the plague together and surviving initially to a escape from the devastated school. As the situation worsens, this group will witness the collapse of society, the outbreak ofother survivors and the breakdown of the old moral values.


H.O.T.D. awakens the attention and interest not by ecchi elements (the "sensuality"), but the theme involving the popular zombies, of course, because even the manga and anime have joined this trend. Adhering some pretty classic clichés and relying on some elements themselves, creating a story not very unique compared to productions that include zombies and similar creatures, but well traveled and very interesting and varied characters, without a little freshness and centered, ie without much freshness. It is a heavy and a lot of blood anime.


Accompanying a small group of characters, and the relatively small number of episodes (remember my theory that most short animes are good), we have a more efficient contact with this story. Of course there is not enough room to deepen with each of the main characters, but did their best without making it tedious, long or too intimate, however, focuses clearly on Komuro Takashi, who unintentionally ends up playing the leading role the group, which incidentally is well composed. No one but the little Alice, is helpless, let alone Kouta, the chubby team, which specializes in firearms.


Yes, lightly following the Harem, there is romantic tension between much of the female members and the young protagonist, and even being heavy and full of action, does not give up a dose of humor to relieve tension. It is a story of survival in an interesting format, not resembling the popular American series The Walking Dead, but with elements that slightly resemble games like Resident Evil, Lef 4 Dead and Dead Island. Although not mention any specific title, HOTD makes it clear that has inspirations in zombie films released by Hollywood, even not playing or parodying a scene from a particular movie, at least apparently.


I do not deny, it is a violent anime, however, if they so demand is best to try Mirai Nikki. Also do not expect a high dosage of terror. Honestly, it's another shonen action, horror almost confined to violent deaths and zombies, that is, does not even scare. There is a good tension, not deny, but it is the least that can be required in this case. I also do not deny that a few times and a half absurd elements, however, which can be relevados, one of them is that each episode (or act) has the DEAD word in the title. As I said, I note that in most cases can be relevados, but others generate a certain gap when not to generate mood.


Highschool of the Dead (yes, now I did not use the abbreviation) follows much the line of ecchi, ie breasts and panties whenever possible, but not distracting nor blurs both the story presented. Not a anime distasteful, as I myself have thought being, however, is not the kind that pleases everyone, but it quite apena watch and still get a taste of "I want more". No, it's not an anime that stands out too much or that ooze creativity, however, can engage the viewer and arouse our sympathy with his young characters in search of survival. Anyone who has watched several films, series and other stories involving zombie apocalypse will not be impressed, and this is an unfortunate truth about Highschool of the Dead.

The Written Review of my Video Review of Highschool of the Dead
Story - 7/10
Highschool of the Dead has a rather basic, typical Zombie romp storyline. It starts off as a normal day in the life of Takashi Komuro just casually skipping class, when he notices an incident happening at the school's front gate. Immediately after a few teachers get killed, he goes onto warn his friends there something going on, they grab a few weapons and zombies overrun the school, in a matter of minutes.
Along the way we meet a few other survivors, and they decide the best way to survive a zombie apocalypse iswork together. They, all together, this merry group of misfits decide to go back into the city, check on the their families and improvise from there, while rescuing survivors in need of help along of the way. It’s really basic, don’t expect anything complicated, although they do establish is it better to travel with a few people or lots of people, which became an interesting plot in itself, but it happened very quickly.


There’s not much to elaborate on the story, it’s a bunch of people just trying to survive by getting from point A to point B. The problem I have with the story. Spoiler Alert. Like a typical zombie flick or horror flicks, the ending is left opened, so it makes you watching this feel, kind of cheated.  


Characters - 6/10


There are seven characters who make up the band of survivors. 

Takashi Komuro, was a typical laid back high school student, until the zombie outbreak happened. Where becomes a leader character, leading his group through the zombie apocalypse by any means necessary. From the very start it shown he has feelings for Rei Miyamoto, so he tries of course save the one he loves, but as the series progress he starts to get along with everyone else in the group. What I do like about his character, is isn’t overpowered, he comes off as second best when it comes to close and long range combat. However he is that person who is willing to step up to the plate, when called for, trying to be the hero, while surviving the apocalypse and his harem. 


Speaking of Harems.


We have Rei Miyamoto, tsundere number 1, plays the role of Takashi’s child friend and main love interest. She comes off as the person who tries to help, but usually becomes the one who needs saving, although she can fight, Takashi always seems to help her in some way. She is rather selfish always bringing something up that annoys Takashi, when he is suffering just as much as she is. Her main choice of a weapon are spear like weapons, as she was part Sojutsu club. Throughout the series, all she really does is interact with Takashi, and really relies on him to pull through.


Tsundere number 2 is Saya Takagi, the brains of the group. She is the most stubborn and arrogant member of the group, because of her intellectuality. She usually doesn’t fight, but however she does use her brains to strategize for the group. She is usually seen criticising Kohta, however grows respect for him over time. She is the megane of Takashi’s harem.


Let’s throw in a teacher/school nurse to Takashi’s harem. Shizuka Marikawa. Despite being the only adult in the group, she is rather ditzy and becomes completely oblivious to her surroundings often not helping out, and being rather useless. Oh wait, she drives for them. She’s not all useless.


And lastly of our harem, is the badass of the group, Saeko Busujima, who uses a wooden sword. She is the most reliable fighter of the group, because of her combat skills, also she’s cool, calm and collect. Saeko kind of serves as the protective big sister for everyone, who also has it out for Takashi. She is given an interesting back story, as she does have something that contrasts the other characters. 


Every group needs a child character, so Alice Maresato fills that role. As the hope of innocence in the world. 


And lastly we have, ourselves, representing Otaku’s everywhere, Kohta Hirano. Despite looking like a typical stereotypical fat useless nerd, he is sort of a badass. Give him a gun, and he’ll headshot for days. Because of his appearance he is kind of mistreated in the group, especially by Saya, who he seems to have a crush on saving her numerous time, but not getting lucky.


Now one problem of the anime is the lack of proper character development. There isn’t enough interactions between the characters to keep it interesting. They all kind of just accept who they are, and immediately trust each other in battles. Another thing I have a problem is after literally episode 2, the main survivors have turned from ordinary day people into, professional zombie killers, like they seen a zombie movie before. Oh wait they did establish they’ve seen zombie movies. 


Animation - 7/10


Let’s get the elephant out of the room. Highschool of the Dead has an obvious thing for fan service. It’s everywhere in your face, big breast that seem to have a physics engine itself, a lot of panty shots and shots around the chest area, even when it’s not even need. Groping and let’s not forget the full fan service episode 6 and OVA. Every female character, except Alice, has big tits, and you wonder how do these girls move so well while carrying that. I wouldn’t know, I’m not a girl.


But aside from the overflow of fan service, the anime actually has really good, over the top zany action sequences. It’s so out there, it is really entertaining to watch. It’s well animated, and moves smoothly, even when scenes really out there. 


However the fan service is just way to much sometime, and really takes away some of the drama or serious scenes in the anime. It’s also kind of disturbing at times. It’s kind of obvious the anime doesn’t take itself too seriously with the overabundance of fan service in your face. Just look at the opening song.	 


Enjoyment - 8/10


Despite the flaws with its rather basic storytelling, and lacking in character development, it is I say enjoyable. There’s just something about the zombie genre, that I like. I think it has to do with the action scene and how they kill zombies in different creative ways, which they don’t use overpowered weapons of some sort, and how they work together to do some of the killings. Yes there is a lot of fan service, and if you love fan service, you’re going to love Highschool of the Dead, if you don’t and get easily offended by that sort of thing, you’re not going to love it. If you’re looking for a zombie romp, Highschool of the Dead plays it really well in terms of typical zombie storyline and characters. I did liked it because of some of the fun action scenes in the anime, and I must admit, being a guy, I did enjoy some fan service here and there, but not all the time. 


Verdict - 7/10


Highschool of the Dead, does a great job in following the zombie genre. It does a good job of gripping you to see which survivors will survive and which will not, and there is small character development, but not enough to make the characters that interesting and likeable. It’s well animated, even though some of the fan service does really get in the way. I’m going to give Highschool of the Dead a 7/10. Despite its basic premise, it does a really good job at executing a typical zombie romp. It’s fun to watch, even though the fan service can get overused.

HOTD get's a terrible rap for it's explicit ecchi content. While there is frequent and blatant fan service, there are themes presented that are very identifiable.
For starters, HOTD is one of the few high school geared animes that capitalizes on the irony of its protagonists being high school students. This irony is exploited to its fullest in a dramatic fashion that binds itself to the plot.
Secondly, the "who will MC-kun choose" conflict is resolved within the first season. The fact that this show chooses a path and sticks to it makes this show stand above any harem comedy/drama/dramaedy I've seen to date. If you wantromantic development, HOTD is the only harem anime that delivers outside of School Days.


Thirdly, the show does not revolve around the protagonist. There are frequent intersections between main and sub plots that leave any viewer guessing as to what will happen on their first viewing.


I could go on for days, but it boils down to this: DO NOT LET THE ECCHI CONTENT AND BAD RAP OF THIS ANIME MAKE YOU THINK IT LACKS DEPTH. It seems that most people who review this anime just jumped on the Hate Train. There is seriously a lot to appreciate here, and that comes from someone who has watched hundred of hours of anime in the same and similar genres.


I cannot believe this show never got the second season it deserved when you have shows like Infinite Stratos becoming best sellers. Seriously, Angel Beats barely manages to develop deeper characters in much more time, and you can't tell me that AB isn't riddled with fan service. That being said, HOTD goes way overboard with the ecchi. It distracts from the good writing in a bad way.

HOTD is the anime that introduced me to the ecchi genre and one of the shows that really sparked by anime obsession. The colorful animation, simple yet interesting story, the blood and guts, and the hot anime babes are something that make this show very enjoyable.
I would like to say that HOTD gets hated on by the dumbest reasons. Many people who've seen this show simply give it crap because of the fanservice. I find this to be pointless because it's a damn ecchi anime, what are you expecting? If your not into anime with tits and ass then look elsewhere because that's what anecchi anime like HOTD is all about.


In HOTD we a very simple story of a group of teenagers surviving the worldwide zombie outbreak. I'm giving HOTD credit for being the first anime to go with the zombie outbreak story unlike other shows. Idk if any other anime have done this type of story but HOTD seems to be the most well known zombie anime.


The characters are all different in personality and looks (except for boob size I guess) but the girls are all sexy, and even badass at times. Even the male characters Takashi and Kota are pretty cool dudes that just want to make it out alive with some hot girls while their at it ;) Saeko Bushijima is still one of the greatest female characters in any anime I've seen, for her good looks and awesome katana wielding skills. It's the perfect woman!


Sadly this series seems like it will never get a proper ending, since the manga has been on a hiatus forever, and the anime still hasn't gotten a second season even after multiple reports and rumors.


If want an anime with fanservice, bloody moments, and a simple yet cool story then give HOTD a watch because it's one of my favorites to this day.

As popular as zombies have been over the last decade, you might expect to find at least a few anime about a zombie apocalypse. But aside from some vampire-themed series where zombies (or ghouls) play a supporting role (Hellsing, Blood+), there hasn’t really been one about people trying to survive hordes of the living dead, until now. While Highschool of the Dead is standard fare as far as zombie stories go, it’s also the first anime of its kind, well-made, and tons of fun.
It’s also fast-paced and occasionally terrifying. Within the first ten minutes, the story shifts from the calm of everyday life to zombiemadness. And by focusing on the students’ mental states as they realize what’s happening and desperately try to escape, the first episode delivers one of the scariest moments of any anime (extra points if you’re afraid of zombies like me). This is the rare true horror anime.


The rest of the series is far less frightening but no less engaging. By the second episode, it becomes clear that the zombies, while innumerable and deadly, are also slow and feebleminded, and our main characters are badasses, wielding swords, bats, drills, nail guns, and basically anything they can their hands on to beat some zombie ass.


With the zombies losing their ability to invoke fear, the story shifts to developing the cast and plot, following the group as they escape the school and seek refuge amidst the chaos. What fear remains comes from the suspense of not knowing what will happen next. Occasionally the focus turns to events elsewhere in the world — Washington, D.C. burning, or a reporter signing off from the news for the last time — that add to the sense of global despair. The story also intermittently considers larger issues like quarantine, citizen unrest, and anarchy, and how they might play out during a zombie outbreak. The main characters are cliches, but they’re cliches done right — each one is likable, and each has a useful part in the story. Above all, Highschool of the Dead is simply fun, with a great balance of fright, action, humor, romance, and (yes even) fanservice.


Where the series falls short is not really in dispute. This is a show that is unabashedly about three things: zombies, tits, and ass. It’s a standard horror story that falls into the standard horror story pitfalls, all while flashing bras and panties in increasingly novel ways (at one point, someone shoots a bullet at a zombie, which passes between Saeko’s bouncing tits as she does a samurai leap through the air). And so there are plenty of stupid decisions and unfortunate coincidences to keep the zombies threatening and the plot going, as well as loads of fanservice shots that will alienate some people. Even if you aren’t bothered by the fanservice and consider it a welcome distraction, episode 6 is pure soft-core porn that will only appeal to those horned-up teenagers who are watching for that moment. Most problematically, the series is incomplete. While the recent resumption of the manga is promising, for three years and counting the anime has been an unfinished product, and given its relative lack of success in Japan, I’m not holding my breath.


Setbacks in story aside, Highschool of the Dead‘s animation is gorgeous, especially the scenery. This creates an interesting contrast between the often awe-inspiring backdrops and the carnage taking place in the foreground, cherry-blossoms fluttering in the wind as someone is ripped to shreds. The animation also excels in the action and ecchi scenes, which manage to capture every detail, be it a bat crashing down on the head of the zombie or a boob jiggling as a girl runs for her life.


The soundtrack, by contrast, is so-so. The orchestral pieces are completely forgettable, but the J-Rock OP and ED songs are excellent, and the use of a different song from Kurosaki Maon for each ending is refreshing. The English voice cast is great, with noteworthy performances by lesser-known actors Leraldo Anzaldua (Takashi) and Maggie Flecknoe (Saya), but the dub has some disappointing edits, making gratuitous use of profanity (“Fuckin A”) and pop culture references that are clearly meant to add to the “cool/fun” factor but come across as trying too hard.


Whatever your views on zombies, ecchi, or gratuitous fanservice, Highschool of the Dead is an important series. It fills a void that desperately needed filling and does a nice job at it, featuring strong production values and direction that results in one of the few truly frightening yet still enjoyable anime. While the common criticisms are entirely warranted, they don’t change the fact that the series is the only zombie epidemic anime around and, even for many of its detractors, one hell of a fun show.

Zombies, boobs, and more zombies. What more can really be said about Highschool of the Dead? I have to say, though, HotD did it better than I expected it to.

What is interesting to watch is their interactions within their group and with people outside it. Even though most zombie shows or games have done it, it is intriguing to see the casts' morals come into play in various situationspitted against them.


Art: 9

The animation in HotD is superb. The action scenes are well-detailed, as for the fan service too. Now, I'm not a big fan of fan service, but I can't deny that every boob-bounce is animated extremely well. Other than a couple of awkward CG moments and mobs of zombies being animated lazily, (can't really blame since animating hundreds of zombies on-screen is surely a pain and money-sink) one could tell that time and care was taken into the actual animation.


Sound: 7

Wow. 12 ED's. That's a lot. Honestly, the sound effects, voices, or the music never captivated me, but that's not to say that it wasn't bad. It just wasn't memorable. As far as I can tell, nothing sounded awkward or out-of-place. The casts' voices matched up with the characters they portrayed, and the music fit in just fine.


Characters: 6

Meh. All the characters were just... meh. I mean, it is hard to develop any of them in 12 episodes. The strengths are the interactions between them and their zombie-infested world, not the characters themselves. Out of all of them, Kouta is the most interesting with the lead, Takashi, being the least. Every other characters' main purpose is fan service, albeit the girls do have more unique characterizations than most other female anime characters whose sole purpose is to give the male audience a boner.


Enjoyment: 9

The big selling point of HotD is the excitement and suspension it brings. There are scenes that will make you sit forward in your seat. I found that my eyes were fixated on the screen at all times with no intention of giving my attention to anything else. The amount of fan service being shown feels like it should be overbearing, but, strangely enough, it isn't. The anime is meant to be for mature audiences anyways. There is also an extremely healthy amount of action that is choreographed exceptionally well.


Overall: 7

HotD is an anime that is meant to be enjoyed. It is not an anime with a powerful theme assisted by symbolic references or motifs. It is anime that captures your attention with zombies, fan service, and beautifully animated and choreographed action scenes. My advice, when you are done watching that highly-acclaimed anime about mankind vs. nature, give HotD a watch. It will excite you to the end without having to think too hard.

The first two episodes looked like it could be something pretty nice.
So they may be worth watching, especially ep.2. has some funny moments and interesting characters. If you'd like to watch some light, a little ecchi action-anime you can go ahead with ep.1. and 2. (Although if you don't like much blood and brutality - rather DON'T.)
After this two episodes it goes worse and worse and evetually becomes much less interesting. There are many many stereotypical ideas, so much dumb but not funny ecchi that it's boring sometimes, often lack of logic, so unreal and unlogical actions that it begins to hurt eventually and (SPOILER:)I counted on some interesting not-the-same-as-in-all-zombie-movies ending at least, but there's practically no story ending at all. (END OF SPOILER)


As for the story: Story for what's going on in the zombie-infected world is fair and logical, I also liked that I could see what's going on with the US president, at a satelite and in few other places in the world - not only now's the main characters doing. On the other hand main characters relations - wich are more important - are often unlogical, unexplained and left in the middle of their evolution.

Art and animation: are pretty.

Sound: You can't complain.

Caharacters: are in my opinion strong side of this anime. It's interesting to see so typical school/ecchi-anime set of characters in the zombie-invaded world.



So it can be fun to watch but there's plenty of better stuff.

But I have to admit - It's better and a little less stereotypical than all american zombie-movies I've watched.

When I first heard about this, I was excited. Really excited. The lack of zombie anime is something that really disappoints me and so I immediately added this one to my list. It was an enjoyable and very nice watch but by the time I finished it, I was kind of disappointed. Let me tell you why:
It started off with a bang. Immediate zombie killing action. It grabbed me and had me wanting more. I had high hopes this could go on to be one of my all time favourites. This wasn't the case, unfortunately 'fanservice' reared it's head. There was even a whole episode,in a short anime at that, dedicated to fanservice. In the middle few episodes, it was fanservice and more fanservice. The anime was in danger of falling very low. Luckily, it managed to pick up again.


Story: 6/10


A group of high school students frantically escaping zombies using swords and bats? Oh the potential! The story showed a lot of promise  but because of the middle episodes, it was like the story had run out of time. Maybe if the series was longer, the story could have been great but the sort of rushed vibe I got from the last few episodes means it was decent, not epic.


Art: 10/10


I thought the art was fabulous. The zombies were designed perfectly and the characters looked very sharp and were well defined. The backgrounds were very nicely defined and the art was really excellent. Though the breasts were excessively large lol


Sound: 10/10


Realistic sounds when the zombies had their heads bashed in. Very nice ending themes...... the opening was EPIC! I loved it and still have the full version on my ipod. The sound really added to the anime.


Characters: 7/10


Mixed bag. Takashi and Kouta were great. I really liked their characters and they seemed kinda badass when they fought. The girls...... meh. Takagi annoyed me with how she treated Kouta, Shizuka was fun at first but then grated me a bit, Rei was awesome at first but then kinda turned pointless towards the end. Though her relationship with the creepy teacher was  interesting. Saeko was good. She would have been one of my favourites if it wasn't for the whole, 'fighting turns me on' thing. Takagi's parents were kinda cool, liked them. The teacher I hated. He actually seemed like a complete bastard. All in all, a mixed bag.



Overall: 8/10


Yes, I gave it a good score. The art, sound, the fights, the enjoyment factor, were all plus points. The sad thing is that the excessive fanservice means that instead of being a 'Masterpiece', this anime is just very good.

Question to all those who said "pandering", "fan service", "ecchi/sex", reduced the quality of this anime.  What is wrong with pandering and fan service?  And for GODS SAKE! what's wrong with ecchi and sex?  Not everything needs to be a Masterpiece to be entertaining.
Now granted the gargantuan boobs on the nurse were over-the-top.  If you've ever seen someone like this in real life you'd find that they're not all that attractive (or at least to me and most of the mature males I know.)  Still, to each their own.
What absolutely blows me away is that this series was dropped afterone 12 episode season.  What happens after the escape from the mansion?  When does "Otoku Boy" lose it and start shooting the undead?  And of course the big question; When do the girls start pulling each others hair out in an all-out cat fight over Takashi?\n\n
I would like to see a continuation of this series, but also possibly a strong ecchi or perhaps even a soft-core hentai version.

High School of the Dead is an anime that I recommend for teens. I say that because of the constant gore, ecchi, and profanity.
High School of the Dead is fairly new, and 12 episodes. I enjoyed this anime, but some parts weren't so good. Too much fan service in my opinion. I can't say I expected any less from a zombie anime, but still.
I watched it while it was still in subs, as the dubs of it are new. The voice acting is great on both parts, but the Japanese version is still my favorite. 
The anime revolves around teens who have survived a zombieattack. Beginning at their school, and spreading further throughout Japan and the world. Takashi, the main character, begins to the animes opening, and like most animes, there isn't a single episode without him. He although is amazing, and cool, he seems like a player. You'll find out why. Although it consists mainly of teens, Saeko manages to save the Nurse after a brave student puts himself in front of her to protect the nurse. There is also some other adult characters, but they come in later.


Unlike most anime/mangas where it takes place in ONLY Japan, this anime shows more. It shows America, for a while with the president.


Although, this anime has a weird starter as the reporters say 2 million have been taken over, they fail to realize that Japan has about 100 million people living there ALONE. So basically, it isn't as much as you think.


HOTD also has some pretty stupid people. Like in, I believe, episode 6, many people are along the bridge, but one woman's child has been bitten. She tries to save it, but, it bits her in the neck( hence a pun, kids are a pain in the neck). Plus, the police must think:

"Anyone who tries to leave will be shot! That way people will calm down!"


Seriously. It was stupid.


But back to the story. This plot line has been overused I admit, with the sex scenes and zombies. But it IS well put together and actually makes sense.I can't express how much an service there is, and I swear it can get BORDERLINE Hentai. So I don't recommend it to little kids. Plus all the violence and gore may give them nightmares.


When I finished this anime, I had a dream where my school was taken over by zombies and a few of my friends survived. I loved the dream, but it was well gory and violent.


So beware of dreams based on HOTD


I gave the characters a 6, because the characters were pretty much used up. From others animes or movie. The originality didn't show very well.


I guess I should wrap this up. So bottomline; it's a great anime despite it's many flaws, and I recommend it to teens and older.  This anime was given an overall 7 by me. Enjoy this anime/manga!

Highschool of the dead.. This revolves on the group of individuals who are trying to survive the Hell out of the undead zombies.. Just like Resident Evil.. This anime adaptation is surely not completed as the things in the manga are still on a roll. (Thought for some unknown reasons, there are still no updates for the latest chapter.)
Going back in the series. This a harem type of anime.. Not only that, it has a lot of fan service because the girls have a huge breasts.. LightningSnow :)

Boobies... Yes... O:
Highschool of the Dead is set in the present day 2010 Japan, beginning as the world is struck by a deadly pandemic that turns humans into zombies, euphemistically referred to by the main characters as "Them" 
The story follows a group of high school students, the high school's nurse, and a young girl as they fight their way to safety through the deadly streets of Japan during a worldwide catastrophic event known as the "Outbreak". As the cast tries to survive the zombie apocalypse, they must also face the additional threats of societal collapse, in the form of dangerous fellow survivors, and thepossible decay of their own moral codes.


Mix all that together and you get an overly-sexualised and wonderfully violent production -- beautifully presented and horrific, even if it doesn’t, in its component parts, contain a single original element. And far be it from me to wonder if the ratio of zombie decapitations to shots of the lead girl’s underwear is a solid 1:1. (I've always believed movies should contain at least two decapitations for every shot of naked under-lady.)


Better to start off with the 

Over all which I'd give 10/10

We've got an assembly of people who rely on each other for survival, in a world crawling with danger. And overall, it's a pretty good show.

Amidst the incredibly overwhelming fan service, there's a lot of great stuff going on in HOTD. There's good action, there's some small romance, there's comedy, there's suspense and there's the reality of the situation in that the characters portrayed aren't really all that special outside their role in the group. 


Enjoyment 10/10 O:

That's not to say you can't enjoy anyone else, Kouta just elevates it to be really enjoyable.There is enough action to make it enjoyable on that aspect alone, but I really feel like Kouta saves the show from being a big flop. He's not the main character, nor is he the most important, but he's there as some comic relief, as well as an integral part of the main cast. You'll find yourself enjoying this show overall, and when you look back, you'll find most of the best parts involved Kouta getting a nosebleed, getting all excited over a weapon, or shooting zombies in the head with a nail gun.Some how dislike fan service anime. You have to give me more than some panties and bras to make me want to watch a show. Thankfully, HOTD realized this.


Sounds is 9/10

Some really didn't fit the scene or some episodes.But what I can tell you is that what they're doing sound-wise in the show works. Where they choose to put music blends so well you won't be able to distinguish it from the animation. Where there is no music, it adds a suspenseful effect to help bring you the realization that we're in a zombie-infested wasteland of a city. So the sound department is definitely solid. HOTD has no characters whose voices don't suit them, and the voice acting is well performed. The drone of zombies does it's job. To be honest, I haven't really noticed background music in the episodes during action scenes.


Art  10/10

they made sure that boobs would jiggle at every opportunity. So there's a good framerate going, and crisp clean artwork.Just putting that out there. The animation is clear, it's well done, and it's eye-catching. The way they animate action scenes is high quality stuff.



Characters would be 10/10

HOTD revolves around only 3 of the 6 main characters, and the only thing bringing it up from mediocre to fair (5 to 6) is our Macgyver. Kouta is not only epic and awesome in his practical knowledge, he's wonderfully written, funny, and someone our inner otaku can relate to.

We've got a clumsy nurse, an egotistical girl, a somewhat selfish and reliant girl, a strong girl displaying leadership qualities, and the male leader. But most of that can be summed up as such. " We have 4 pairs of breasts, one is useful, a typical male lead. I don't mean to demean it or anything, but the other characters get so bogged down in fan service that you could seriously give them any archetype and the show wouldn't be much different.

Here are some boobs, sometimes they show butts too. Honestly, character is underdeveloped in HOTD. 



But in all seriousness, High School of the Dead has actually been very enjoyable overall.  


Really though. Its an equal disturbution of ecchi and zombies.

Some boobies and some zombie won't be that bad will it? :O :P

Watching the first episode left me in amazement. This show gives off and eerie aura to it  but with a hint of a childhood love story to it. I'm a guy who is not into the whole horror genre but this is an exception. After watching the first episode is making me wanting more and wanting to see the characters to survive this world. This show is in my top 10 list for 2010.

HOTD had the potential to make my top ten of anime with plot alone, but several characteristics of this particular anime caused it to fall down on the ratings for me.
Story: (10)
A zombie apocalypse occurs and several high school students and their school nurse are doing their best to survive the global pandemic. THIS IS AN AWESOME PLOT! My goodness I've been waiting for them to do a zombie apocalypse anime forever! On the other hand, this is a harem anime so there are of course multiple girls fighting over the same heroic guy who is just trying to keep everyone alive. I'm not muchfor harems myself, but you know what? There are freaking zombies so I watched it all the way through!


Music: (8)

The opening and closing songs were catchy and addicting, so I didn't feel the need to fast forward through the opening.


Art: (6.5)

Granted some of you who have watched this may be going "WHAT! The art was amazing!" Yes, I do not doubt this for a second. The zombies were kick-ass! As were the guns, scenery, blood, guts, character expressions, etc. Only one thing got me off of the fan bus for the art and that was: the ever present, impossibly huge, exaggerated movements of the breasts! My goodness people I mean these things were... I rest my case. If you've seen HOTD you know what I'm talking about. Then again, maybe it's because I'm a girl and actually have a pair that I can be irritated by them. At ease men! Enjoy the exaggerations as I continue my review.


Character: (9) 

The individual character development was decent. The connection between the main character and his complicated relationship with one of the females is explained, and they continue on blah blah blah. What I really liked was that each character really was different in personality. Sure it's a harem so the girls all like the same guy, but what's great is that: that is the only thing they have in common! One of the best characters is a total nerd that turns bad ass once the apocalypse starts and isn't the least bit hesitant on doing what needs to be done. Some might say that makes him kind of psycho, but he still gets along well with others and the group and is out for the protection of the people he is with. 


Enjoyment/ Overall: (7)

Seriously if it weren't for the constant need for nudity and giant breasts then this would've made my top then. Other than that, this anime was pretty good and i do suggest it to my guy friends.

Hope you found my review helpful!

This anime is one of the first I watched so later on, I'll probably finally see what's going on. 
At first, the story being told is pretty impressive. You see what happens and what they were all like before the zombies took over. And then, you see them either running away from them, fighting, or having a team and then abandoning them to save themselves.  
The main characters slowly team up and even though some of them are enemies, they end up as friends. All of it was usually interesting and I never noticed anything bad about this anime. But I'm not sure ifyou would consider it the best of all zombie apocalypse animes because this is the first and only one I've watched.

HotD is an educational exploration of Newton's Laws of Motion, taking the form of a zombie apocalypse story.
But seriously, you know why you want to watch this.  My only real criticism is that I'm not sure that the screenwriter knew why you want to watch it, resulting in some legitimately grim moments which are a bit discordant with the overarching theme of "boobs are fun!"
I think it's worth noting that overall HotD does a pretty good job of recognizing the difference between objectification and titillation, treating most female characters as humans with breasts as opposed to breasts with attached humans.  It does spendan awful lot of time focussing on the breast end of the equation, but I hope I might be forgiven for being at peace with that.

I write this review having only seen 1 episode but what an episode it was.  I'm hooked and I cannot wait to see how the story progresses.  The first thing I will tell you all is to watch it.  I don't care how you do it, burn it, borrow it, steal it, and when you do you will be hooked.
Story 8: Only one episode into this series but it seems like a basic zombie survivor show but with what seems like underlying subplot for the other characters involved.  As the series go on the story could become much more intriguing dependingon where the story goes from its original generic zombie plot.


Art 10:  To my eyes I enjoy the way it looks.  There is a good amount of detail involved, and the colors are bright and vibrant.  This series is very pleasing to the eyes.


Sound 9:  Nothing like the sound of a baseball bat whizzing through the air just before it crashes on the skull of some zombie student.  It is japanese audio which I love to hear and the voice acting is spot on.  I can really hear the fear and the pain in these characters voices.  In all I love the sound.


Character 8:  Haven't been introduce to all the characters yet but they seem like what you get in most high school anime the leader, his love interest, the nerd, the samurai girl, the noisy girl, etc.  I like these characters but they are nothing new and so far they aren't that special.


Enjoyment 10:  The fights are awesome, the panty shots are nice, the emotions are real.  I have to say to sit down and watch this I was just blown away with how much I enjoyed it.


Overall 10:  Now if you were to add up my scores and average them out this series would be a 9 but in the end it all comes down to the enjoyment of the show.  If you really enjoy something regardless of the other factors you will continue you like it.  If you like the way a girl looks but you don't enjoy being around her then she isn't all that great.  If she is okay looking but is funning with a great personalty then she is way better to be with.  Anyway that just my opinion, and I hope it helps,

I love Highschool of the Dead! I found this anime to be awsome even without the echhi elements. (though I welcomed the echhi,lol)  I truely believe that the writers of Highschool of the Dead do an excelent job of presenting the mental & moral challenges that one would face surviving in a Zombie Apocalipse.  Yes, they pervert it up a lot, but that's there very-unique style and I absolutley love it!  The characters are the only real weak element to me(6/10), because the character development isn't as deep or involved as it could be.  I think those who dont like itwere expecting a action anime first , and a comedy/echhi/ect. anime second. But, Highschool of the Dead was always, from the begining, an Echhi anime first, and all the action/comedy/ect. stuff next; and as far as I know, no one else make an echhi anime with this level of action & gore without it being some weird hentai.  They find a nice ballance between the echhi/action/comedy elements of the show. That's what makes this show a rare gem, and I really hope they make more shows like this one.

Highschool of the Dead is your typical, run of the mill zombie flick about high school students trying to survive in a zombie apocalypse, but that isn't necessarily a bad thing. What surprised me was the great quality of the animation and soundtrack, and the action scenes. This anime featured a lot of gory, over-the-top action scenes, even for a zombie flick. Coupled with the soundtrack, it made it a pretty thrilling and enjoyable experience. 
Regardless of the fact that it has a lot of aesthetic appeal, Highschool of the Dead is lacking, due to it's cliched plot and it's unrealistic characters, who I didn'treally care about. Frankly, after watching many films/series from the same genre, it felt expected and predictable. Additionally, the over-sexualisation of just about all the female characters and the sexual nature of many scenes just felt out of place; wrong even.


Highschool of the Dead is what it is: your usual zombie flick, nothing more, nothing less. Still, it was a pretty good watch.


Rating: 7/10

*This is an archive from my Anime-Planet account, and this was posted on Christmas Eve, so this is outdated as of now*
WARNING: The following review contains Strong Language, if that is not your cup of tea, I suggest you do not continue. Thought I'd warn you.
Critic's Log - Earthdate: December 24, 2012. Review #27: Highschool of the Dead
On November 30, 2012. I went and saw the new James Bond movie Skyfall with a friend, and after the movie was over, we went to the library and I checked out some anime because my friend usually suggests animes that I haven't watched yet that were availableat this library. She had me check out Gun x Sword (which I previously reviewed) and another anime called "Highschool Of The Dead". I remember my brother telling me that the show is full of "tits and ass" and I told my friend that and I asked her if she'd seen it and she told me that she hasn't seen it yet but she insisted that I watch it. Well, I've held back quite a while and since Christmas is tomorrow, I'm in a holly jolly mood and I can't wait to BITCHSLAP this anime for this review! This anime is obviously going on the naughty list. So... Let's shoot the fuck out of Highschool Of The Dead!




Takashi Komuro is just an average high school boy, that is until an infection breaks that turns people into zombie-like creatures. Alongside his friends and a school nurse, they fight their way out and continue their journey to find out what exactly is going on with the world.




There! That is the basic gist of the plot of this bloody mess.




To be technical, this is a Madhouse production and to my surprise. The animation actually looks really good in this show. In fact, it's probably the only good feature in Highschool Of The Dead (or H.O.T.D. for short) Madhouse is known for their really good production quality from back then as well as today and the animation is mostly good while having a few problems. One is that the zombies could've looked a little better but they still look alright to a degree. The big problem I have with the animation department is them throwing in fanservice in the middle of a damn action scene. Not only that but there are many scenes with lots and boobies and plenty of panty shots. Expect to see a few scenes of nudity too. I wouldn't mind the fanservice if it wasn't thrown in from scene to scene from time to time. That's my major bone to pick with H.O.T.D.






The music by Takafumi Wada is not that memorable to me, but there are some worthy mentions in the music department for Highschool Of The Dead. The closing credits feature 12 songs with one song for each episode. It's kind of nice, but there are some songs that really feel a little out of place. When it comes to the opening, I just have a few things to say about it. The opening theme kicks ass, the visuals are pretty cool for the most part, and it's a song that is stuck in my head for a while. The highlight on the music is definitely the opening.




When it comes to Voice Acting, The Japanese Cast is decent but it's not really an all-star cast. Junichi Suwabe plays Komuro just fine for the most part. Marina Inoue (the seiyu of Yoko from Gurren Lagann) is fine as Rei Miyamoto, Eri Kitamura is okay as Saya. Junko Takeuchi (The seiyu of Naruto from...Naruto) sounds nothing like Naruto and yet plays her role just fine. Miyuki Sawashiro plays Saeko pretty well for the most part. Nobuyuki Hiyama is pretty good as Kota Hirano *Record Scratch* Kota...Hirano...? You mean that this character was named after Kouta Hirano, the manga artist and creator of Hellsing.




Ok, there's no coincidence. The Kota Hirano you see in H.O.T.D. was modeled after the real-life Kouta Hirano. You know what? I liked Hirano throughout the series, he was alright.


Now that I've brought up the subbed version of Highschool Of The Dead, it's time that I mention the dub. OH...FUCK! Before I mention the vocal talent, there's something I must mention. Steven Foster is responsible for writing the Adaptive script as well as being the ADR director for the dub of this show. If you know what I'm talking about. It's THAT Steven... Motherfucking...Foster. He's a ADR director that I assume proudly shows that he doesn't give two fucks about the original material regardless of what it really is or how people would react to the dubs he produces. The only dub I think was a good one he did was Cromartie High School. However since he produced this dub, expect a few things.


1. Characters swearing up a fucking storm. I don't know how many times the F-Bomb has been dropped.


2. He has a tendency to portray the characters as mean-spirited while the original Japanese intent of the characters tends to differ.


3. Some rare adaptive script writing that has some awkwardness.


4. Pop culture references that don't make sense in the context of the story.


5. A mixture of over-acting and wooden acting.


What Steven Foster should do is try to re-create the intent of the original material and maintaining the spirit of the original Japanese intent instead of making a bastardized juvenile adaptive script that mocks the material instead of being faithful to it. If other dubs produced by Steven Foster have the same problem, then this dub has the same old Foster bullshit from before. When I mentioned the juvenile feel of the adaptive script, it's a little surprising to admit that it actually fits the show to some degree. Now that I'm done mentioning about Steven Foster, I'll actually get right down to the dub. It's not good at all, it's pretty bad. Leraldo Anzaldua is okay as Komuro but sounds off at times. Jessica Boone is alright I guess. Maggie Flecknoe is way off as Saya. Mark X. Laskowski is not all that great as Hirano. Monica Rial sounds way off as Shizuka (the Nurse). Taylor Hannah is a bit decent as Saeko, nothing more. Brittney Karbowski (Black*Star from Soul Eater, Pride from FMA: Brotherhood) plays a little girl and it's nothing to write home about. Hey! the English voice of Krad (Illich Guardiola) voices Shido in the dub and he's alright for the most part. Still, the dub is pretty bad and it is much easier to watch this one subbed. Thank God that's over and done.


When it comes to characters, they are poorly written. Especially the female cast. Komuro is a little uninteresting to me and comes off as a bit one-dimensional at times. Rei is alright, Saya is a rich bitch (really, she is), Shizuka is...uh... well... she doesn't really do a whole damn lot. Saeko is a little interesting. Hirano is fun to watch at times and a character that I liked for the most part. The characters are still not written that well and that's another big flaw.


The biggest flaw I see is the story. It's sort of a average story about high school except that there's an outbreak of zombies swarming around mixed in with some gun action and bouncing boobies as well as some panty shots. It's a real fucking mess and I feel as if the show is confused itself because the school plays little to no part later on unless you count the students as part of the school setting I guess. I will say that the weirdest thing is when Arisu is thrown in the mix of characters. She's just a 7-year old and having the majority of female characters being labeled as "sexy characters" seems to not mix in too well, at least there's not any innuendos thrown in during her moments. As much as I am trying to hate this show. I can't fully hate it for some reason. The fanservice is a bit fucking annoying, but the action scenes were sure cool. The animation was a solid effort by Madhouse and I do label this anime as "brainless entertainment" because this show doesn't hide from what it really is. This anime doesn't feel rushed or slowed down either, so that's also a good plus. Wanna know an extreme mindfuck? Tetsuro Araki is the director of this show and he was very well known for his direction on Death Note.


HNNNNGGG!!!


This really is a mixed bag kind of anime, but this will be memorable for a while. The ending isn't all that great but what do you expect after sitting through 11 episodes of brainless entertainment. If you have extra time to spare and want to see Zombies getting shot to hell as well as seeing some nice animation, give this anime a try. Just get ready to be bombarded with big bouncing boobies as well as panty shots, Cleavage, and some nudity. In other words, expect a whole lot of fanservice before you sit down and watch it. It is quite entertaining either way.


Highschool Of The Dead is available from Sentai Filmworks. The manga written by Daisuke Sato and illustrated by Shoji Sato is available from Yen Plus. An OVA called "Drifters of The Dead" has not been released stateside for some odd reason, which is kind of a shame to say the least.


With all that said, Highschool Of The Dead is a mixed bag with a mess of a plot, a unmemorable soundtrack, poorly written characters, and a pretty bad dub. It's action scenes and animation is what saved the show from being absolutely awful. The fanservice should be viewed as "Take it or Leave it". It's surprisingly an entertaining show for what it is. This is an anime that may be hard to hate, but it is hard to like if you are trying to take it seriously.


I give Highschool Of The Dead a 5.7 out of 10, it is SO-SO!


Feel free to leave a comment, and Merry Christmas.

Why do people take this show so seriously?
A lot of the reviews I have read have been taking this show way too seriously. Its zombies and ecchi. I don't really think it was supposed to be serious. This show is just supposed to be really enjoyable, its extremely thoughtless. All it really is, is guns, girls and zombies. What more could you want?
The story is pretty simple, a zombie apocalypse starts and all hell breaks loose afterwards. So, an average bum, a ginger, a fat guy, a bitch who's a bitch, the badass chick who's only purpose is to be badass, the doctor thats practicallyfanservice as her tits jiggle up and down every damn second, a loli and a dog have to run run till they're save from the zambies.


The story is pretty generic and the characters are all stereotypes. Takashi, the main character of main characters is really just an average dude, all the chicks in the group want to get banged by him, I've never seen that before! *cough* harems in a nutshell *cough* Rei is your basic dumb bitch who's purpose is to be that dumb bitch in zombie movies that is well, dumb. And as we go on, all the characters are a stereotype.  So to finish off the characters quickly:


Saeko: Basic badass woman that knows kindo and can use katanas and stuff and has some bad past. Never heard this before.


Saya- Your basic rich girl that brags over how smart she is. I really don't have to say anything else...


Alice- Why is this character even here? She's just a plot device and literally has no purpose to be here.


Zero- It's a dog, you always need a dog!


Kouta- You wonder what, I have made fun of every character, but this guy, holy shit I love him. Its an otaku that knows how to use fucking guns! The explanation is stupid but I don't care, he has some genuinely funny dialogue and how can you not love him?


You wonder what I see through all of this? A tribute to all those zombie movies that started zombie movies. I love it man. This is really what this reminds me of. And I appreciate the writers and directors for doing this cause as much as I really don't like some of these characters (other than Kouta), I do enjoy seeing them kill zambies and getting into shitty situations.


And besides all that, this show is a lot of fun. There's action left and right and genuinely some funny dialogue. Like I said before this show isn't supposed to be taken seriosuly, it's just a lot of fun as we see a bunch of big tittied woman and 2 guys try to survive a zombie apocolypse. Overall, I had fun with this show.


To get it out of the way. The animation is pretty good. I liked some of the art, the zombies looked menacing, the animation is smooth and decent. Also, I fucking love the OP, gets me pumped up every time as the first couple of seconds open up with a guitar solo getting my anus prepared for tits and gore!


I recommend this show actually, if you want a simple and brainless anime to just entertain, I easily would recommend this. 


7/10

"It'd be Perfect if it Weren't for all the Risqué Scenes"

After ten episodes, I've stopped worrying about how a series will continue on people surviving a zombie influx; I'm rather impressed how the producers have kept the whole thing entertaining. But they don't need to keep injecting cleavage (or, bouncing breasts), and the roll-in-the-hay (or bathtub) scenes they seem to relish pushing. I've been trying to find what Highschool of the Dead reminded me of and suddenly,minutes ago it hit me..You know these parody porn being released from time to time?Well....This manages to be even worse.So with no further adue here's my review of Nightmare on Boobtastic Street.
The story is what it says in the synopsis.Basically a highschool setting,a bunch of students,who found themselves into the middle of a zombie apocalypse and their struggle not to die,plain and simple..So how,one has to wonder,an anime with such a good premise fucked it up in a galactic scale?
First you have to look at the group of people this aimsto please with its' massive doses of fanservice,and by that i mean of course the simple minded teenage boys who are easily pleased by some light action and boobs so huge they come with their own moon.And trust me when i say massive fanservice.You can almost imagine the writers saying to each other:"oh we didn't put some panty shots there in this corner of the screen,let's put some more for no obvious reason"!!!This is called the fap effect.When a butterfly flaps its' wings in China some youths fap like there's no tomorrow in the rest of the world.But it has movie refs as well..Like the Boob Matrix scene for example..Oh no that wasn't good,scrap that..


"But at least the characters are interesting"..Please have some strong drugs near you,you're going to need them,trust me..First we have Takashi.He is so perfect i got the impression that he lives in a yogurt commercial.Everything he does is perfect.Even his catatonically stupid decisions end up perfect..Why?Because he's a perfect badass...Then you have Rei,who as far as i can tell is bipolar..One moment blames Takashi for the death of her boyfriend(who decided bitchslapping a zombie was a good idea)and then wants to fuck him till the end of time.Kouta Hirano,the gun nut was my favorite of them all.Then Saeko the kendo sadistic girl.Shizuka the useless nurse who doesn't seem to have the faintest idea of medicine or what's happening but has the biggest boobs seen on a mammal.There were some others but i can't bother to remember them.


"Yeah but it was fun,right"?....Hell's no.You know the infamous "2 girls and a cup" vid?That was much,much,much more fun that this and i threw up 3 times in my mouth in a space of 2 ms before i actually vomited copiously.At no point did i feel connected to the main cast so even if they died,and unfortunately they don't,i couldn't care less.Throughout the anime i felt like the main characters weren't in such a great danger as we were led to believe.Only one seemingly major character dies in the beginning and that's it.The rest of 'em were alive and well enjoying panties and boobs.No real struggle,no sense of danger whatsoever and the action part was like watching your grandpa trying to dance...


The only good part was the animation and the opening soundtrack.Other than the show,i think,was just made to cash in on the zombie craze of late.But when you make a show about undead creatures and turn it into the wet dream of a 14yr old fap enthusiast with boobs that jiggle about defying the laws of physics and then throw some ridiculous story about nukes and stuff(of course 'Murica blew them all fuckers into the middle of next week)which should have affected the whole of Japan,but somehow only renders the powergrid useless...I'm sorry but it doesn't cut it for me.It could have,it should have been better.But the writers of the show didn't want to make use of the story they had in hand,they decided boobs and panties were the way..And judging by the reviews it had some positive impact on a major sum of the viewers..Well i can safely say that i'm not so soft on the head and i'd rather cut my left leg off and beat my self to death with it than ever even thinking again in the slightest anything to do with this horse shit.

So this is my first review, and I am by no means a great reviewer or can go in depth as to what really makes me enjoy something (really the most important part of a reviewer of all things), but I will try and briefly (oops) explain why I really enjoyed Highschool of the Dead contrary to popular opinion. I must say now that I might be a bit biased, as I have been a huge fan of zombies practically my whole life, although I do think I bring up some valid points.
Highschool of the Dead is by no means a fantastic story or onethat has great character development (largely the most important factor in an anime for me), although this anime fulfilled its true purpose, making it fun to watch the characters kill zombies. When I walk away from finishing this anime, I wont remember the heart throbbing characters like that of Clannad or the Monogatari Series, I will remember how much fun it was watching zombies get sliced and diced, and killed by other means. Since I feel like I am getting kind of lost here, I'm just going to switch over to bullet points now;


1: It has a good dub. I myself normally watch subs, but HotD actually had a great dub with some hilarious voice lines. A good dub or a dub in general only increases the quality of life for the non-Japanese speakers, and I am thankful for that. I must admit, I did not hear how the original sub sounded, so I cannot draw comparison between the two.


2: The genre is not often explored. Now I am sure there are other animes out there that might feature themes similar to HotD (most notably Gakkougarashi!), although it's pretty rare to stumble upon an anime that features the modern (George A. Romero) zombie and has a pretty high production value. If you are a fan of zombies, I think you'd really enjoy this anime, also I don't think you are left with many other choices.


3: The lewd aspect. If that is even the right word for it, basically the fan service and nudity present throughout the show. This is one of the main bases for criticism and I can agree, it's just holding the story and the characters back. Most of the female characters have huge goddamned breasts, and have "those" scenes to show them off. It only takes away potential time from the rest of the episode to further develop the story among other things. 


4: All the other stuff. The story) was OK, I could keep up with it and enjoy it for the most part, although among some scenes like a certain bathroom scene... (see the previous point) I did not enjoy. Art) was good, everything looked pretty good and the theme of a zombie apocalypse really gave the artists a lot to play with when it came to killing zombies among other things. Sound) The sound was good. As said about the story, there was a lot of opportunity for some cool sounds being the zombie apocalypse. The voice acting, the action sequences both sounded great.  I don't know much else to say about that in particular. Character) The characters are pretty hit and miss. I will let you discover for yourself what you might think, but some I've really come to admire, and others, are just really pathetic, *cough* big boobed teacher *cough*. Enjoyment) This is the best part of the anime really, I touched up on it somewhere in the mess above. But it was really fun to watch, minus the "lewd" scenes.


In conclusion, 8/10, and an end to my actually not-brief review of HotD, and first MAL review ever. Sorry I could not elaborate more deeply as to what really drove me to enjoy it, I tried my best. I do not think this anime is as bad as people say it is. Don't watch this anime thinking you are in for a serious story with great characters, you are here for some great zombie killing and action sequences, and some story and character development as a side to complete the dish.

This anime was really funny and awesome to watch if you love high school anime and lots of fighting. These 12 episodes are packed with lots of ecchi scenes which make it even better, not to mention the beautiful art work. 
The story is very interesting and suspenseful without a doubt, each episode is filled with mad hype and lots of fan service. Defiantly would recommend this anime if you love high school anime, a little romance, and fan service! The ending and beginning are mad and wish it got a second season, but even so it takes you on quite the journey.
My only "con"with this anime is that the fan service can be a bit much at some points. The dialogue at many points also could have been written a bit better. It also would have been a lot better if they gave us more character development with some characters, but overall it was a great anime.

This is an anime you hope that they do a fullmetal alchemist and redo it once the manga is done. It's only 12 episodes but it's built to be anywhere from 24 to hundreds. It over does the underwear shots and breasts, but it is a good plot. The anime is way too short, can only hope they extended it when the manga ends or redo it entirely. The characters are diverse and all that i didnt like was there was not a true tsundere character which is my favorite character type. It is a japanese Walking Dead but only for a male audience. Irecommend if you want a little sadness knowing it's so short and are looking for a good show.

All these children trying to write reviews are embarrassed because there's boobs in their anime. 
The top review is pretty fair, recognising the good point of the show despite the fact that they "really, really dislike fan service anime." But then looking further down, people are giving 2s and 3s just because the anime had lots of boobs, saying hyperbolic things like "this is one of the worst anime I've ever seen." 
I disagree with all these opinions. Let's look at some more quantitative elements of the show before we dive into it's ethos. First, the artwork is great. The zombies are scary, the girlsare sexy, and the fight scenes are exciting (this is to be expected, since it's directed by the same man who made AOT). Also, there's genuinely great character developement. You can really see the characters changing and acting realistically as they struggle through their various challenges. Just this fact alone puts this show above 90% of modern anime. Another way this show stands out is its great pacing. At no point in the show did I feel like the storyline was making unnecessary turns, nor that it was going too quickly.\n\n
At it's core, Highschool of the Dead is about instincts. It's not an intellectual show promoting some grand philosophy or showcasing complex psychological battles. I think this is part of where the show gets misunderstood; some people only acknowledge these aspects of a show. Highschool of the Dead is meant to make you feel rather than think. It focuses on two primal thoughts: fear and sexuality. These two complement each other, and if you take either one out of the show, it would probably only be an 8. It's this magic mixture that leads me to rate this show a 10, despite it's complete lack of an intellectual agenda.

I might be a little biased when writing this being the anime that got me into the whole otaku business. To start off though, this was the first fully fledged anime I watched when it was first released in 2010 around September. I was 10 years old. You might think that it’s messed up to watch an anime like this at the age of then but I think otherwise. This was one the best experiences of my life watching this show.
Being regarded as one of the most perverted shows of all time is an understatement. This went above and beyond. The amount of fan-service inthis show is overly done which I don't like. It did make the show majorly popular which was the whole point of it being there in the first place. 


Art: 10: Despite being one of the most perverted anime if not THE most perverted, the amount of detail is astonishing. The animation and art style is amazing. it`s just plain beautiful. The two guys who made this anime and manga might be huge pervs but they are geniuses to art and animation.


Sound: 7: Besides and whole zombie apocalypse concept and great art style, Maon Kurosaki became famous for her album made for all the ending songs of the show. Her voice is just amazing. It’s very unique and beautiful and all the songs in the end are different which gives much to enjoy. If I have to say, this anime has to have one of the best soundtracks of all time. Not only that but all the lyrics actually correspond to each episode it was part of and they actually have good meaning to them. But there is one problem; the English dubbed version was horrible. The voice overs were really annoying and didn't fit. Even if they did fit they pissed me off with their high pitched voices. For one, in the Japanese version, Takashi says the F-bomb one in the beginning, correct? Maybe some minor language throughout that right? In the English dub he says the F-bomb at-least 20 times throughout the series which I didn't see was necessary Some might like it but in my opinion it was unnecessary and the Japanese voices were far better.


Characters: 6: After years of watching the show over and over again, I now notice that the only good character was Hirano, Alice and Shizuka. Takashi has literally no good traits about him. I hate Tsunderes like Takagi but she`s slightly better than the rest. I guess it’s her character design and her family. Saeko is one of those female characters that are all powerful. She is a bit overpowered than the rest. Alice and Zeke go along with Hirano; they are the only ones that are good. She’s cute and helpful. Rei is that annoying clingy female character and Shizuka is a dumb blonde which actually gives personality to the group surprisingly. Hirano finally comes in, the otaku, geek, nerd who actually has a good personality and shows character development throughout the story. He`s the only character that most of us actually love. i wouldnt care if the others died just keep Hirano, Alice, Shizuka and Zeke.


Enjoyment: 10: I’ve been doing research for 4 years and this is still the only anime in existence that involves the zombie apocalypse concept. Maybe because the concept is so farfetched that it isn’t attempted by any except the Sato brothers who as we’ve seen, are either crazy or geniuses or both. This being the first anime I actually watched (besides Bakugan, Yu-Gi-Oh and the other crap that used to show) I took major enjoyment in it. But now as I watched it today I still get that geeky feeling every time Hirano comes up or when the Humvee pops out. Being the only Zombie anime, it’s a must see if you done mind watching some really perverted scenes.


Story: 7: It’s very realistic in terms of what is going to happen in the apocalypse. The government falling and how humans are the problem and not the walkers, and the whole society falling apart thing. My problem with it was that the creators focused more on fan-service instead of the story. It should’ve been more like The Walking Dead depicting how the humans are scarier than the walkers themselves. If the creators had put more of that, and maybe still have the excessive fan-service, it would’ve been near perfect.


Conclusion: The anime was great if you’ve seen it and as you’ve seen I`m still a little biased towards it. It’s a much watch if you don’t mind excessive fan-service and nudity. With the supposed season two coming in Fall of 2014, after 4 goddamn years, it will make even more money and become even more popular than it is now. Those who have been waiting as much as me cross your fingers and wait to go full nerd as the next 12 episode come soon.
